div.stage: Enter Duke, and Traine; who meet from the other Doore Fernando and Officers: a Crye without of Ioy, from the People.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Fernando, we bring you joyfull hearts, instead of such Triumphall ornaments, as your high Actions merrit.

sp.speaker: Fernando.
sp.p: You honour me too much Sir, but if the Princess own my indevours! I may hope the scandall of that letter, sticks not on me.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Wee have found the foul coppy of that forg'd Letter, in Corbinos Closet, and the Author of it, shall ere night, suffer as he deserves!

sp.speaker: Fernando.
sp.p: Pray Sir forgive him, as I do, his designe has done you good, I had not venter'd full so farre, but to wipe off that scandall; — and now Sir, for Marianas sake, I beg that you will pardon her old Father.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
She shall have all his Lands immediatly, but I must deterre others from the like horrid actions; —if I had believ'd him! and imprison'd you; what a mischiefe might that Barbarous beast have ledde me to! Princes who pardon such crimes, will neer be free from the like Vipers, who devoure the good Names of the innocent, 'tis our work to cherish truth, and vertue, and to banish such Monsters as Corbino, from the converse of men: he is condemn'd to the Dungeon
while he lives! 'tis fit that you retire Fernando.

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: Now they are gone, I will congratulate your victory, with some good hopes, that Silviana may comply.

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.l: Florio is my good Angell still; yet I must pitty Thee.
Vnhappie Youth, expos'd in • o a crow'd
Of Beauties, where thou freely art allow'd
To looke, and chuse! invited to enjoy
A full variety! in hope to cloye.
Or • ix thy fancies, which by Nature grow,
Beyond the power of satisfying so!

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: If Youth, of Beauty must be still afraid▪
Why were those Glorious Objects ever made?
Beauty to Age, is like a painted Fire,
Warmes not; though it create a faint desire,
That mocks the appetite of Old mens Eyes,
With Youthfull wishes, but neer satisfies;
Cause Age repines, much oftner then recants
Past follyes; still lamenting what it wants!

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.l: If brightest Beauties cannot youth reclaime!
Nor raise an Old mans fancy to a flame;
By such experience taught, we may conclude,
Our Passions, doe our Iudgments still delude;
Which leads us on to Idolize a Face,
Without inquiring the intrincique grace!
Florio take heed, when Lovers soare too high,
They seldome finde a lucky Destiny.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: My fortune, and my fate in love, will neere
Be worth my care, nor worthy of your feare;
I will within impart what I have done,
And shew, how Silviana may be wonne;

div.stage: Enter: — Camillo and Borosco with three Officers.

sp.speaker: Camillo.
sp.p: Corbino is got o •• at Fernandos intercession, and wee are safe.

sp.speaker: Borosco.
sp.p: Safe indeed, and freed from all imployment in the State, these strangers are now • ix'd, unlesse you Camillo help us to remove u'm!

sp.speaker: Camillo.
sp.p: I have away to do it, if you Gentlemen will joyne, to free your selves, from this forraigne yoake.

sp.speaker: [All.]
sp.p: Wee▪l live, and dye with great Camillo.

sp.speaker: Camillo.
sp.p: Thus then fellow Souldiers, at the next generall sally, we will ingage our two young Leaders, into the midst of the Enemies, and then retreat so suddenly, they shall be cut in pieces, ere they see their danger.

sp.speaker: Borosco.
sp.p: Good, very good; but when will this Sally be?

sp.speaker: Camillo.
sp.p: Suddenly I hope, for since Fernandos returne, my scouts bring newes, that the Enemies whole forces are drawn up, to countenance their men, while they repaire the works Fernando slighted; so that when he has slept a little, I will set Florio on Fire, to seek their own destruction; by begging the command my self, that he and Fernando may take rest, which will inflame them to goe with us, as private men.

sp.speaker: Borosco.
sp.l: Loose no time then, for while such mischiefe cooles,
VVe may be 'taine in our own traps, like sooles.

div.stage: Enter the Princess with Rossina, Philora, and Floremella.

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.p: How faires Rossina? does Florio yet approach?

sp.speaker: Rossina.
sp.p: He has no time yet Madam, and I am not in h • ste.

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.p: He loves but little, that cannot sin • e a time to shew it.

sp.speaker: Philora:
sp.p: The love of such young men, is like stubble set on Fire; which gives so short a heate it warm's not.

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.p: What is your opinion of Fernando's gravity?

sp.speaker: Philora.
sp.p: He lookes of late, so much concern'd, with his great Offices▪ that such inconsiderable things as wee, are not worth his thought, and is preingag'd to, I believe.

sp.speaker: Floremella.
sp.p: 'Twere well if any of us, could get one of these constant Lovers, to change our breed! —our young Gallants, doe throw their Hearts at Ladies • ea • s so fast; we cannot take them up, before we finde them tumbling at an others f • et.

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.p: A very good state Argument Floremella. —

lg.l: —Ift come to voting! thou shalt have my voice
For both, or either of them, at thy choice.

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: Pray Madam, let these Ladies stand a little off, that I may impart an a •• ai • e of consequence.

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.p: Rossina pray go not away, you are out of hearing now.

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: 'Tis time Madam to let you know, that Fernando loves, and is of quality fit for you to own: • his respect • so great, he presumes not yet to begge the honour of one visit, nor will own his quality, untill this warre be over, that his actions, may parallel his greatnesse; and yet for your sake Madam, is become a volunteere.

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.p: I am oblig'd my Lord to you, that think me worthy of the man, you honour most! but I shall admit no courtships, from the greatest Prince in a disguise; nor is it fit for me to guesse at, what he designes to hide.

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: My businesse now, is onely to invite your Highnesse, to look • on Fernandos actions favourably, and when his merrit has rais'd such a value of him, in your heart, as you could wish he were a Prince! I here ingage m • honour, you shall finde him such.

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.p: I have no wishes of that Nature Florio, nor do I fancy such a Romance; but who ere he be! that wares such vertue in so bright a case! he merrits my civillity. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter at one side Duke, Camillo, and Officers, at the other side Enter Florio a little after.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: What you have urg'd Camillo, I approve; and you shall sally with what power you please, since we have men enough, our frequent skirmishes, will weary their new Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: Another sally Sir so soone!

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Camillo undertakes it with his Brigade alone; you, and Fernando shall both rest.

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: Pray Sir lay no commands on us to stay at home, when great Camillo sallyes; I know Fernando, will be more troubled then my selfe, our businesse here is to gaine experience, and we must loose no opportunity to learne.

sp.speaker: Camillo.
sp.p: Will Lord Florio allow us Natives, no time to shew our conduct? and our courage, to serve our Prince? without his assistance; as if he coveted, the sole glory of the Warre.

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: You do mistake me my Lord, my businesse is to learne; I have no thought to Eclips your glorious actions, which I desire to immetate; and with your permission, do begg the Dukes leave, that Fernando, and my selfe, may • ight as Volunteeres, only to observe how you command!

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: By no meanes Florio.

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: I must not be deny'd Sir; for I allready suffer by my not sallying last, your people say, I have got honours, and offices enough, to keep me from farther hazzards: and this will be Fernandos fate too; if he goe not with Camillo! Sir, wee are resolv'd to be in every sally, which if you deny! our credits will call us to aske your passe, that so we may returne to our Countries, with our honours safe.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: If I cannot intreat! nor yet command your stay; I do unwillingly consent; —Camillo, they are in your care.

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: Wee will both waite on your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Camillo.
sp.p: Was not this well design'd Borosco? I knew how to inflame young Florio so, as to presse on, to both their ruines: —we must charge home at first, they once ingaged, we will retreat, and leave them to a sure destruction.

sp.speaker: Borosco.
sp.p: His fancy of Volunteeres, gives oppertunity to place them both in our first Ranks, without jealousie.

sp.speaker: Camillo.
sp.p: And by them, I will place a score of my boldest men, with direction, that they suffer not the strangers to advance a foot before them, for the honour of our Nation: — You Borosco, shall stand with the Reserve, just without the Port, and my Order is, not to move till I send for you; which shall be too late to rescue our fine Gallants; I have given Orders out allready for a present sally; —wee must make haste; —

lg.l: Before it do grow dark, that no mistake
Our thus well order'd plot, may useless make;
A mischiefe well design'd, we count halfe done,
Before the active part, be yet begun. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter from one side Duke and Lords: Enter on the other side Borosco.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Is Camillo yet gone out?

sp.speaker: Borosco.
sp.p: They are, and my Troopes are drawing forth!

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Though I hope Camillo will have no need of your Reserve; yet be vigilant Borosco: be vigilant as you will answer it with your life! I have by much intreaty, prevail'd with Florio to stay with me.

sp.speaker: Borosco.
sp.p: I shall observe my orders, I have the Generalls direction Sir.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
And mine! go now, lest you be stay'd for! —Longino,
Exit Boros •
draw all my horse guards from the market place, immediatly unto the Port, but go not out, till I give you Orders; I will be ready too.—

lg.l: —Accidents in Warre, do too often show,
That no experience, can all harmes foreknow.

sp.speaker: Tigillo.
sp.p: This is the strongest sally Sir you ever made, and yet you apprehend it most!

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: I do indeed, take more care now, then formerly, because I now know the value of those I venture; besides a slight mishap to us beseig'd, may fright our friends abroad, from sending in their promised aydes: —I have intelligence Tigillo, of some Treacherous designe upon the strangers lives; Camillo envies them, but if any Plot to their prejudice appeare, Camillos life shall answer it. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Longino.
sp.p: Never was sally thus trebly order'd! —we may thanke Florio for all this providence, and to say truth, he does deserve it; from the Duke, and us; though I feare Camillo loves him not! —hark, they are at it now, —this is my Post.

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.p: All is not well, the discontented Lords, had private, and late meetings.

sp.speaker: Longino.
sp.p: The Duke has Spyes on them.

div.stage: Enter the Duke and Florio with his Traine: Tigillo meets him from the other Doore.

sp.speaker: Tigillo.
sp.p: Camillo does retreat Sir; on the first charge retreates! and hath left a small party ingag'd in • ight!

sp.speaker: Longino.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Leade my guards out, and bid Borosco advance with speed, or he shall Dye for his delay!

sp.speaker: Longino.
sp.p: I shall Sir. Exit Longino.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: This looks like a designe as full of mischiefe! as Camillos heart of envy; it makes me tremble, to think what danger, brave Fernando may be in.

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.p: Camillo retreates Sir; in great haste, without a stroke retreates: nor will Borosco stirre, Longino cannot make him move; Fernando is ingag'd past hope of rescue.

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: Fernando is betray'd Sir: we must be quick, or he is lost!

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: If Camillo still retreat! the designe is plaine; and time for me to hazzard now? Camillo dyes for this base Act, —This is the plot, this the treachery! death, and confusion fall on Camillo. —my Horse, my Horse. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter the Duke, Florio, and Traine: Camillo and his men meet them at the Port.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Where is Fernando?

sp.speaker: Camillo:
sp.p: Lost by his own rashnesse.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Or by your base retreat, without a stroake, destroy'd! there's a reward for Treachery, or Cowardize, which you please! faces about! [Kills him.] —Tigillo, I command thee on thy life, to kill Borosco at the head of all his Troops, and lead his men after me: there mischiefe is too evident!

sp.speaker: Camillo.
sp.p: I have my due, that did ill execute, what I so well design'd! our Retreate was too suddaine; not to ingage at all, made our designe [Dyes.] too plaine! —

sp.speaker: 1 Lord.
sp.p: This confession will please the Duke.

sp.speaker: 2 Lord.
sp.p: The noyse growes low'd my Lord, from the Tower, we may see what is doing in the Camp.

div.stage: A Charge afarre off, not low'd then a Retreat: Then Enter Duke, Florio, Longino, Tigillo and Officers.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: We came too late, to rescue brave Fernando!

sp.speaker: Tigillo.
sp.p: Borosco is dead Sir; as you commanded.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: I will reward thy courage, and thy faith Tigillo. —a thousand curses follow those Traitors to their graves, death cannot expiate their villanies; —But we must now consider how to redeeme our Gallant friend!

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: By a quick Sally, give them no time to breath; but with all your strength, fall on their head Quarters; and fetch him off by a strong hand: —give me the conduct Sir; and if I faile, Ile fall in the attempt.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: This suits with Florios gallantry, and friendship to Fernando, but if your successe, prove short of your designe? he, and wee may so be lost:—I rather think to ransome him for Gold.

sp.speaker: Souldier.
sp.p:
Fernando Sir is well, and by the Enemy well us'd, he has a small guard, and a great Tent, in the head Quarter, I got the word, and so escap'd.
Exit Duke and Traine.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Let us consult within.

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: Stay Souldier, have you the word?

sp.speaker: Souldier.
sp.p: I have Sir; 'tis Ferrara.

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: Dare you be my guide this night, to fetch Fernando off? if I with a few more, do hazzard to his Tent? which you seem to know!

sp.speaker: Souldier.
sp.p: Yes Sir, I dare dye in such good company!

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p:
No more, take that purse, and attend me at my Lodging; I'le suddainly be there.
Exeunt severally.

div.stage: The SCENE changes to a Camp, and in a great Tent — appeares the Duke of Ferrara with Fernando and Officers.

sp.speaker: Ferrara.
sp.p: Be not dejected Sir; such accidents in Warre, are frequent, and the bravest men most subject to your misfortune.

sp.speaker: Fernando.
sp.p: To be your prisoner Sir, is not my trouble, but to be betraid! so basely forsaken by Camillo and the rest, without a stroake! lookes like a Trechery, you understand not! —it must be so; Florio was too easily perswaded to abide at home! —there, there was the designe, for my captivity! that in my absence, he may be the man! —what is my ransome Sir; name the summe, and I'le procure it; — and returne like a consuming flame amongst 'um.

sp.speaker: Ferrara.
sp.p: No summe, no Ransome, for if I understand you right! the young favourite Florio has betray'd you, he jealous that your services, might out-shine his pretences to the Princess Silviana, and make voyd the Dukes solicitations on his behalfe; (for thus my Camp discourses) to my amaze and wonder! that the fond Duke should reject me; and chuse so unknown a man, as Florio! but if his designe be, to raise a private Gentleman unto his Dukedome? —'tis great injustice to chuse Florio, before you; — (I hope this angry man, will doe my businesse!) [aside.]

sp.speaker: Fernando.
sp.p: The Dukes doatage is so great on Florio, that he knowes no joy like his advancement! —But Florios falshood, calls my revenge▪ to cut off all his hopes that way, for if Silviana do consent, to Crown his aspiring thoughts! this hand, shall at the Alter, stabbe him to the heart.

sp.speaker: Ferrara.
sp.p:
You are free Sir; and this moment may depart; all Ceremony lay'd aside, I take my leave; loose no time Sir in such affaires,
delayes are dangerous! Francisco, — command the Captain of the watch, to attend Fernando to the Citty gate. I wish you happinesse.

sp.speaker: Fernando.
sp.p: I accept your favour to depart, but am not yet resolv'd to what place.

sp.speaker: Ferrara.
sp.p:
By all meanes returne to URBIN Sir; now you are free! —Let not Florio boast, so strange a Victory!
Exit Ferrara.

div.stage: Fernando sits sadly by a Table a while silent.

sp.speaker: Fernando.
sp.p: I understand all your kindnesse Duke, but did not think, I had appear'd so tame! so meane! to remove Florio, for his pretence; Camillos treachery, was from a just envy, because he lost that favour, which I gain'd; —I can excuse him, and Borosco, on the same account, but Florio to comply! and the ungratefull Duke! —they merit my revenge.—

lg.l: —If guilty both! it is decreed;
The Duke, and Florio both shall bleed.

div.stage: VVhile Fernando set silent Enter Florio alone, the rest stand at Doore Fernando starts up and drawes.

sp.speaker: Fernando.
sp.p: Treason, treason.

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: Guard thee Fernando, Ile dye by thee: but where is the Enemy? I see no danger!

sp.speaker: Fernando.
sp.p: Thou art my danger, what mischiefe brings thee hither in disguise!

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: Mischiefe Fernando! have you no better welcome for a friend.

sp.speaker: Fern:
sp.p: For such a Friend! that dar'd to sleep at home, when I was lost.

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: Oh barbarous! you know the Dukes commands, and importunities were such! as I could not refuse to stay; and you consented too; yea I have blush'd ever since, and come now by a greater hazzard, to wipe off that shame, which I could not prevent.

sp.speaker: Fernando.
sp.p: You rather come with this excuse, to invite me to a second trust, by which you, and the rest, may some more certaine way destroy me; but to such faithlesse friends, I shall returne no more.

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: Does this hazzard, and my try'd friendship, merit such language? the Duke too, is well repay'd, for his severe justice on Camillo, who himself, with his own hand slew, for his base Treachery to you: —and on his command, Borosco fell, by young Tigillos Sword: —what expiation do you seeke? what satisfaction for Camillos crime, can you demand? if all this be argument for so unworthy a distrust? how can innocence be justifyed? —Pray Sir take more time to judge of this, and now trust your selfe with me: I have the word, and can securely passe, I have a bold party too, who stand ready at the Port, to favour our Retreate.

sp.speaker: Fernando.
sp.p: I need them not, I have my freedome, and have taken leave, can passe whither and when I please, but my Judgment on all this, I cannot suddenly summe up, and therefore will not goe.

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: What testimony can you wish? what assurance have? beyond this voluntary hazzard of my life, to lead you to the Princess Silviana; from whom, you may inquire my friendship, and my Faith! if this be an abuse! you have then a cause to show your courage, and may call me to account! but if all this convince you not! leave me here a Prisoner, in your place; and so revenge those wrongs you onely dreame of.

sp.speaker: Fernando.
sp.p: No, to betray, is worse then to be betray'd! I scorne to act a treachery that I so much condemne in others; —I am now resolv'd to goe, and to suspend all further thoughts of jealousy or discontent: —and if my passion for the Princess, hath mis-led me into unworthy thoughts of you, or of the Duke; I shall gladly do any pennance you'l inflict.

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: Your own sence, for your mistake, will prove a sharper pennance, then we can wish.

sp.speaker: Fernando.
sp.l: Though I have Arguments for my distrust,
Yet Florio, and the Duke may both be just!

div.trailer: The End of the third Act.

div.head: THE FOURTH ACT.
div.stage: Enter the Duke, leaning on Florio's shoulder, follow'd by Fernando, Longino, Tigillo, Lords, and Officers.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: TO what strange hight Florio! will thy daring heart aspire? at what point of honour rest! that I may rejoyce thy dangers past, without new feares for more ensuing hazards comming on.

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: The Gods directed what I did, and friendship could expect no lesse, Fernando would have done much more for me Sir.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: I do believ't, but yet methinks, your large soule might afford some roome for me, so much a friend! as to be consider'd in my concerne for all the dangers you are in.

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: Such a presumptuous thought in me, had been a crime, when great Fernando's life and fortune was at stake, against a compliment!

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
I yield, Florio must ever conquer. Be Generall Fernando, and you Longino, Command the Horse; —Tigillo take presently the Citty Keyes from young Camillo, and be you Governor of URBIN; he shall know, that obedience to his Prince, is above his duty to a Father;
—if any can make cleare proofe of more conspirators? they shall have all their lands, and goods for their reward; —now Fernando! did I apprehend with cause? were not my private cautions of Camillo, worthy your best Providence?

sp.speaker: Fernando.
sp.p: I could not guess at Camillos mischiefe I confess; so great a mallice! from a gallant man, I never met before; but when Envy, and Revenge (Ambitions twin children) doe wedd their Parents cause, no reason can so naturall a rage withhold, nor any limits such unbridled fury bound! when the high hopes, that all their fancies aym'd at, were cut off, by those honours heap'd on us. This makes me reflect with some compassion, on your severity to persons of their worth, who had no crimes, but what grew from too much vallew of your favour Sir; I wish that our successes had been lesse, or your rewards not full so much! Though narrow hearted Princes often blush at merits beyond their wills to recompence, yet some great soules like yours, too often overvallew, and reward such services as ours, when a kind mention, with a smile, would amply satisfie: pardon Sir my sorrow for the losse of those two great men, who fell on my account, that shortly must resigne all the envyed Offices I hold; and thereby shew how small an Argument their hasty Envy took for such a ruine as they design'd on me; which in few dayes might have been diverted; for this Siege ended, I must be gone Sir, as I have frequently to you, and them, declared in publike; and now to leave so many mourne • s, where I have deserved so well! will very much eclips my memory when I am gone.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: I have no argument but their crime, to justify their punishment; though your clemency might have spared them; a lesse severity would not become me.

sp.speaker: 1 Lord.
sp.p: Camillo at his death, confess'd his guilt▪ and exclaim'd against his own too hasty a retreat.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: We know too much of their conspiracy. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter the Princess with Philora, and Ladies in her Chamber.

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.p: I wonder why my brother stayes thus long, from seeing me.

sp.speaker: Philora.
sp.p: He has had but little time to order his affaires; Camillo, and Borosco being both dead, their commands are of great consequence.

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.p: I have not heard of the like villany! —what newes Tigillo? how does my brother?

sp.speaker: Tigillo:
sp.p: Well Madam, but much troubled for Camillos wickednesse, against those he so much loves; he sent me to excuse his visit to your Highnesse, untill he have dispatch'd some great affaires, that do require his presence.

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.p: Are the two strangers well?

sp.speaker: Tigillo.
sp.p: Not both Madam, Fernando has some hurts: but nothing dangerous.

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.p: Is not my brother much pleas'd to have his Florio safe return'd?

sp.speaker: Tigillo.
sp.p: He is indeed, somewhat fonder then I could wish, but can your Highnesse fancy a fitter subject? for so high a concerne; who ere beheld a Nobler object? for a Prince's favour?

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.p: I do not know so fit a man, to make his favourite as Florio; but to dote so much on him, as to consider none of us! takes from my Brothers Judgment, and lessens our love to him, I am glad to see him pleas'd, but to see him lost in admiration of a man! is not well; — Rossina come,—

lg.l: —Let us retyre, untill the Duke appeares,
To raise our hopes, or satisfy our feares. Exeunt.

div.stage: As they are going off Enter a Servant.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p:
Madam, there is an Officer without, who desires accesse to your Highnesse, he has a Paper in his hand, he sayes of great concerne! and must himselfe deliver it.
Exit servant.

sp.speaker: Silviana.
sp.p: Admit him, —Tigillo, pray stay in the next Roome.

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.p: Madam, I come from the Enemy, sent by the Duke of Ferrara, to mingle with your Troopes, which sallyed last; —amongst whom, I got into the Towne, thus in private, to excuse to you alone, the mischiefes by this Warre, brought on your People.

div.stage: He offers her a Letter, she refuses it.

sp.speaker: Silviana.
sp.p: No, 'tis beyond excuse Sir: but why this to me in private? if from Ferrara sent! why not in publique to the Duke.

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.p: 'Tis not his purpose Madam, to humble himselfe unto your [Hee kneels.] Brother, though Ferrara do desire thus to lay himself at Silvianas feet (to shew what love can doe!) his courage is too high, to stoope before the greatest Prince on Earth. [He rises.]

sp.speaker: Silviana.
sp.p: Tell your high hearted Master then, my brothers interest and mine, are so mingled▪ that neither his force, nor subtlest Art, can ere devide us; tell him I despise his Love, who with an Iron rodd does wooe; — his former Menaces became him better, then this flattery; Ile heare no more. [Offers to goe out.]

sp.speaker: Officer:
sp.p: Then give Judgment Madam ere you go, on the guilty person you despise; for if my love cannot prevaile! to excuse what I have done; Let me by your doome fall; —Ferrara is at your mercy.

sp.speaker: Silviana.
sp.p: Sir; Your excuse is bolder then your Crime, thus to surprize me in disguise, is as offensive as your Warre; and works the same effect in me, who see through all your designes, but can discerne no love! —'tis our Dukedome you expect, and so much labour for, not me.

sp.speaker: Ferrara.
sp.p: This Warre, and my disguise, are both the effects of Love Madam, and at worst, can be look'd on but as tryalls, whether by your brothers, or your own aversion, I have been rejected! —I ledde my Army hither, to remove his constraint on you, (as I suppose) and now freely offer up my selfe a sacrifice, to your dislike, if by that I fall neglected! such is the power of Love, it makes the greatest dangers, most delightfull!

sp.speaker: Silviana:
sp.p: Such Romances take not me, your first approaches, and all your Treaties were accompanied with such unreasonable demands, and such Rude threats; as shew'd you were a man of Blood; — no Characters of gentle love appear'd; — I remember also the Succession was your maine Article: that must be setled, or you would not have me! by which you bound my Brother from a second Marriage, and would take me, as an appendix to the Crowne! and through all this! I must now discerne your unvisible love! — no Sir, though the Principallity must be my beauties foyle, to raise esteem in you: I can set a value on my self • , above the Dukedome you ayme at.

sp.speaker: Ferrara.
sp.p: Madam:

Though I come hither, lifted high, on the delightfull wings of hope; dispaire must now be my Reserve, for my Retreate: yet thus by your scornes, arm'd for your Revenge; I shall rather smile, then shrinke at your Brothers malice: after this repulse from you! and shall glory here to fall, Lov's Martyr, at your feet.

sp.speaker: Silviana.
sp.p:
You shall be safe from all harmes here Sir, —I will secure your safe returne, though I answer not your hope, you shall not suffer
Enter Tigil: by this rash visit; —Tigillo, pray see this Officer safe convey'd to his Campe.

sp.speaker: Ferrara.
sp.p: No Madam, now I have put off that clowd, which did secure my passage hither, (by which my undertaking is perform'd,) to put it on againe, may looke like feare! as if I valued safety, at a higher rate then Honour? I will therefore with an open face, —

lg.l: —Now I have kneel'd at Silvianas feet,
Pass on, through all the dangers I can meet.

sp.speaker: Silviana.
sp.p:
My endeavours, and my wishes, do concurre for your security, but if you suffer ought, by your own rash choice: I shall take care that you have no pretence, to lay a blemish on my innocence: —Tigillo waite on the Duke as I direct: —I will answer it to my Brother.
Exit Princess and Ladies.

sp.speaker: Tigillo.
sp.p: I shall not doubt to do, what you command Madam.

sp.speaker: Ferrara:
sp.p: I am sad to think Tigillo, on those evills, which Silviana compells me in honour, now to Act.—

lg.l: — For since no submission, can make her relent,
VVe are oblig'd to fight, though we repent. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Florio as in his Chamber sitting sadly, Pedro by.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: Madam, What want you? will you think your selfe into the other World?

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: I wish I were so happy! no Melina, I am doom'd to more disasters here.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: Pray impart the trouble of your minde, that I may argue on your griefes, a little to divert you.

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: Thou wilt raise my distemper higher, by thy discourse! but yet I'le try; —I was thinking Melina, how much better it had been to have stay'd at home, and sufferd all my Fathers anger; —still saying no to his unjust commands; I might so have shew'd a much more becomming courage, by such sufferings, then thus by • lying them; —for had he forc'd me to the Church! (so often threatned!) he could not there compell me to comply; — I might at worst, have dyed on that account, with honour! —as now with infamy!

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: If you pursue these thoughts! they will distract you; 'tis childish to look back, when you must pursue, the Fortune your first thoughts have led you to! —does not the Dukes love, grow higher and higher still? —why then do you create evills in your fancy? beyond what can happen!

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: Oh Melina! had I not better dye? then ever own my selfe a Woman! when the Duke shall finde the favourite he dotes on, to be a transform'd wanderer! how will he hate himselfe, and me, for placing such a scorne on his great Name for ever: —I love, and honour him so much! I dare not seek the happinesse I wish, but must undiscover'd dye; —to save my reputation, and his Fame.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: These are waking dreames Madam.

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: And then, if Fernando, should discover me! how will his honour be concern'd? what vengeance will his just anger finde out for me? —there is but one way Melina, besides Death.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: May I be trusted with it? you have made me Sadder then I look'd for.

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: The Siege ended, Ile returne, and take a Cloyster; where I will wash away my shame, in Penetentiall Teares; —and if I dye before▪ I do conjure thee Melina, to conceale my sex; I have adventur'd what I can, to get an honourable death, and 'twill not be; which makes me apprehend, some sadder Fortune does attend me.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: Madam: I have thus farre against my judgment, and my interest, been wholly govern'd by you; but now I see you will destroy your selfe, I am resolv'd to let Fernando, or the Duke know your condition, to prevent a greater evill.

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: How Melina! wilt thou betray my trust? and prove a Traytor at the last! thou dar'st not do so great a villany!

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: Rather then see you ruin'd, I will do any thing! —what crymes? what guilt frights you into this dispaire? I will no longer be accessary to your destruction, now I can bring you off with honour.

div.stage: She offers to goe off, Florio rises and steps between Melina and the Dore, and drawes.

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: Stay Melina, —so, now 'tis my fault, if you discover me, by all my hopes▪ 'le k • ll thee instantly, unlesse thou dost now sweare, not to reveale me; speak quickly: —for when thou art dead, I will by my own hand dye by thee.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: Hold, and I will, —by this I swear, as you desire.—

lg.l: —But that I do a greater mischiefe feare,
Your threatned death, should not have made me sweare.

div.stage: Enter the Duke who drawes and offers at Pedro. Florio steps in.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: False villaine, to lift thy hand against thy Lord!

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: I did assault him Sir, in my unjust fury.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Florio has no unjust fury, Pedro must be faulty!

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: By truths selfe I sweare he is not: the fault was only mine, [Embraces.] and Pedro has made me see my error: —look Sir, we are one againe.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: I do believe it now, —But what then has caus'd this great distemper in you Florio? —am not I yet worthy to be trusted with your concernes?

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: How can I expresse more value of your favours? then I have Sir, I wish not to live an houre beyond them, by all that's good, I do speak Truth.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: I know not how to urge a trust, you are resolv'd against: but I plainly see, you have a troubled heart, —say Pedro, what is that afflicts your Lord? is it within my reach?

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: Had you come a minute sooner Sir? you might have known, but now I have sworn.

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: Pedro no more:—Great Sir, I do confesse I have a grief, which I do shame to own, least you should despise, what you now seem pleas'd with: for my heart knowes no griefe, but doubts to hold your favour!

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: You can have no interest, that I will not make mine: Speak Florio, is it Silviana?

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: No Sir, but what ere it be, I will in time orecome it, and appeare before you with a cheerfull face againe: I beg you will no more inquire it, for I am well already; your kindness cures all the evills, ever can belong to me.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: And do I appeare so slight a man? that you can feare my favours cannot last! which still increase! you wrong me much, by so unjust a jealousie.

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: No Sir, 'tis my own unworthinesse, that frights me; lest I in time, appeare uncapable of these honours you allow me: I finde the stock of credit I have gain'd, begins to fayle so fast! that my distractions make me giddy, on the thought of a senister Fate.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: No more of this it troubles me. —I am now going to my Sister, whom I have not seen since my last sally: shall I have your company? [The Duke imbraces him.]

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: I attend you Sir.

div.stage: [They go off, and Reenter at the Princes Chamber with her.]

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: I have had so much to do Silviana, I could not get free before: and am now come to beg your assistance, in an affaire of mine.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Of what nature Sir: your looks shew trouble in your minde.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: My trouble is for Florio, who has some hidden discontent, that will I feare take him from us! —and I have hopes, that you may finde, what he will not reveale to me.

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.p: Do you take me for a wise Woman brother? such as deale by Magick; how is it possible? that I should know Florios heart? if hee'l conseale it!

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: I onely wish you would inquire; —he may say more to you, then me.

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.p: I obey you Sir: —pray my Lord be pleas'd to satisfy the Duke, by telling me, what those troubles are, he so much apprehends; and if the cure do lye within my reach, you shall command my best endeavours to serve you.

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: I dare not dally with such Excellence; —one great trouble is, lest Fernando, (my deere friend,) should perish, by your neglects Madam.

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.p: You see brother, he has no concerne of his own worth naming; he dotes on Fernando, more then you on him.

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: I never can expresse more gratitude unto the Duke, and you Madam, then by recommending Fernando to your thoughts, what can be fancyed in a man? more then we all see in him?

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.p: Birth to equall mine!

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: Does that onely hinder?

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.p: I cannot yet resolve you.

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: I beg Sir, that you will obtaine me the Prince's leave, to bring Fernando to kiss her hand.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: I shall not deny your suite Florio, as you do mine; —Sister, pray admit his visit, when I appoint the time.

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.p: You have my consent my Lord, when the Duke approves it?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Madam, I prize • this favour you allow,
More then wreath'd Lawrels, on Fernando's brow.

div.stage: Florio kisses her hand and leades her off not seeing Fernando Enter.
Enter Fernando who seeing this returnes in anger.

sp.speaker: Fernando.
sp.p: This is a dagger at my heart, Florio is false, and I too tame! Fernando going back.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Fernando stay.

sp.speaker: Fernando.
sp.p: I beg your pardon Sir, for interrupting of your privacies.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: We have done, and were now parting: —What newes from the Enemy?

sp.speaker: Fernando.
sp.p: Our out guards have taine a Prisoner, who sayes, on some intelligence from Ferrara, they are resolv'd to storme us, as their last hope, and do prepare for it with speed.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: We will be ready for 'um; —

lg.l: Our VValls are strong, and men so brave within! Exeunt. Omnes.
To startle at their storming, were a sinne.

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: I have got leave to bring Fernando to the Princess, on a private visit; but where to finde him, I know not! — 'tis some happinesse to do a friend that courtesy, which none can do for me.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: Yes, I could do more for you, if you'l permit me? 'tis strange that so much wit and courage, should produce such folly, and such feares! —I finde my judgment, is worth twenty such as yours, and I must be bound by oath, to make no use of it.

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p:
Pray leave d • scoursing, and finde out Fernando; I would speak with him; —make hast, my heart growes light to think what joyes I bring Fernando.
Exit Pedro.

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: Oh Sir; I have sent to seek you!

sp.speaker: Fernando.
sp.p: And too soon have found me, thou grear dissembler!

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: What meanes Fernando, by this injurious language to his friend?

sp.speaker: Fernando.
sp.p: I have no Eares to let in thy bewitching charmes a second time!

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: Was ever Injury like this? what have I done, to loose your favour?

sp.speaker: Fernando.
sp.p: Thou Courtest the Princess, against thy faith given, and my trust; I have no words for such a Treachery as thine! those flattering Eyes, and thy false Tongue, shall nere deceive me more.

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: Can Fernandos great Soule, admit so meane a thought? of such a Faith as mine to serve him!

sp.speaker: Fernando.
sp.p: I have no time to talke, — Death is due for such a Treachery as thine, were this place sit to throw my fury on Thee!

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: You lessen your own worth Sir, by raising groundlesse jealousies on me; did not my love, and innocence forbid! I would by silence seem to own the guilt you fancy, and with open Armes, now meet the Death you threaten; and I so often wish for! —But I am more your servant then you discerne, and dare not comply, to bring so great an evill, as shedding innocent blood! on Prince Lorenzos head!

sp.speaker: Fernando.
sp.p: Ha! dost thou know me?

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: Yes Sir; or I would not shun death proffer'd from your hand! which I have by many hazards sought! though not on this account! —yet I can shew great Lorenzo, a better Argument then his unjust jealousie, to sheath his sword here! for I have (too confident of my intrinsick Vertue,) contracted such high guilts, your Highness never can forgive! (yet Silviana shall be yours.)

sp.speaker: Fernando.
sp.p: Though I understand thee not, thou hast said enough, to raise my wonder, above my anger! 'till I know more!

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: Have you never seen a Face like mine at Pisa?

sp.speaker: Fernando.
sp.p: Not that I remember, or did ever know!

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: Nor shall do now! —on second thoughts, your unknown Enemy, calls for Death Sir; I have wrong'd you much! and my selfe much more. [Florio opens his Armes.]

sp.speaker: Fernando.
sp.p: No, thou hast charm'd me by some Magick spell, I dare not touch thee, —who art thou?

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: You should never know, if by any hand but yours, I could by death have been conceal'd! —can you not yet call to minde your unfortunate Cousin Celestina, in this face? —have my crimes, alter'd me so much?

sp.speaker: Fernando.
sp.p: Celestina as a man! do all the wonders I have seen! can it be?

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: Too true Sir: —pray let your Sword now do, what I have [Sh • kneels.] so often sought from the Enemye! —I would dye Sir; 'twas my businesse here, and 'tis high time that I were dead, this place, this hour is fit for such a sacrifice to wrong'd Innocence; for I have defam'd Innosence; rais'd a scandall on the name of Vertue! —the honour of your grear Family is concern'd in my disguise; if I survive this scandall I have rais'd? your Lenity will be condemn'd, as if you had comply'd! and so the great Name of Florence will be howted at! —but when I am dead, you may conceale my Name, and not participate my shame; who do now appeare so strange a Monster to my selfe! that I shall blush to death, if your Sword prevent me not.

sp.speaker: Fernando.
sp.p: Is lovely Celestina then! my envyed Rivall, for the faire Silviana.

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: You have no Rivall Sir; the Princess sent me now to bring you to her, on a private visit: —do you believe me yet?

sp.speaker: Fernando.
sp.p: As an Angell sent from Heaven; I believe thee! but thy good newes cannot stay these Teares, for thy selfe now shed: —poore Celestina; I have heard thy sadd story, and thy ill natur'd Fathers Tyranny, thou fled'st from; — all thy friends have mourn'd for thee as dead, or so lost! as never to be found againe!

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: I am not so happy Sir!

sp.speaker: Fernando.
sp.p: Nor I so miserable to loose so great a friend; —how shall I devide my heart? between Silviana, and Celestina; to thee I owe my life twice sav'd, and all my interest in Silviana, by thy helpe gain'd: —all that I have, my being and my bliss, I must derive from thee; my deer, deer, Celestina.

sp.speaker: Celestina.
sp.p: This kindnesse is more comfort, then I did ever hope to finde on Earth! I wish that I coiuld die, thus happy, before the Duke does finde his Florio is a counterfeite! —I feare.—

lg.l: — His honour will ingage him to dispise,
A wandring Woman, in so strange disguise.

sp.speaker: Fernando.
sp.p: Lay by thy feares, and put on such a hope as will become thy Vertue, and thy Birth; this Romance will end well, the fond Dukes friendship, will soon turne to love, when he shall see a possibility that Florio may be his! dost thou love him?

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: I have not dar'd to entertaine a thought, that might lead me to hopes of such a happinesse on Earth.

sp.speaker: Fernando.
sp.p:
Let that hope, take its first rise now from my Endeavours; for when I see my time to unmaske us both, i'le do it for thy
advantage Celestina; —but why did you thus long conceale your selfe from me?

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: Feare to offend you Sir; which was my quarrel with Melina, who thretn'd to discover me to you, when the Duke found our Swords drawne.

sp.speaker: Fernando.
sp.p: Is Pedro Melina too! —where get you such manly hearts? and vigour to act such wonders!

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: Alas Sir, I did but draw my Sword, and wave it 'bout my head, my weak blowes, were only in search of death; but it seemes the powers above, propitious to my innocence, have turn'd the rugged Fate I sought, into glorious Trophies I deserve not; discontent at first, then dispaire, threw me into all the dangers I could finde: — but this discovery, has reduc'd me to a Woman, I can now tremble at my own shadow, my courage is quite gone, and I now shake, to thinke, what I have done!

sp.speaker: Fernando.
sp.p: You must hold up your Character, till I see time to owne you, and to declare my selfe; which shall be suddenly, my deare Celestina, thou shall't be my good Angell still; —wee'l visit the Princess, and first reveale our selves to her; — trust me to mannage your interest with the Duke, as you have mine with Silviania; wee must now prepare for the great Interview:—which the Enemie so much desires; —take courage Celestina, —

lg.l: —Where Beauties force, with vertue does combine,
They cannot fayle to prosper a designe. Exeunt.

div.head: THE FIFTH ACT.
div.stage: Enter Clara, and Pedro severally, in great hast.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: DEare Pedro, take care of me, they say we shall be storm'd, and sack'd! pray what is sack'd?

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: All the Mayds above fifteen years old, by the Enemy found in Towne, must be put in Sacks, and thrown into the River.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: This is a short warning, to provide against so great an Evill! but I hope you may finde favour to preserve me, sweet Pedro take me to thy care.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: I shall do my best for thee, if I fall not in the Assault! a good Day pretty one.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Why in such haste?

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: I am commmanded to attend the Interview, and must be gone.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: I understand not what that is!

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: Why, 'tis a Committee of Inspection, on the Princess Silviana.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: You confound me Pedro, with hard words, is it any thing about the Sacks? and the River! I am so afraid! I know not what to doe!

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: Take courage Clara, I will preserve you, as my friend: I shall be missed, if I stay longer now!

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Thank ye deare Pedro; —but I will hide my selfe how ever!

lg.l: —This young white liver'd Boy may courage lack!
To keep me from the River, and the Sack.

div.stage: Enter At one Doore the Duke of URBIN, with Fernando, Florio, Lords, Officers, and Guards, who range on that side.
Enter The Duke of Ferrara, with Lords, and Officers who range on the other side.
Enter The Princess Silviana, with all the Ladies, who stand under the SCENE, between the Rowes of Men.

sp.speaker: Urbin.
sp.p: What be your demands Lodovico? what is the Argument of this Parlye, you have desir'd.

sp.speaker: Ferrara.
sp.p: Silviana is my Argument, whom you detaine more like a Prisoner, then a Sister you ought to love, and honour, by matching with some Prince, fitter for her Birth, and Beauty, then a Nunnery! which your thrifty kindnesse, would perswade her to.

sp.speaker: Urbin.
sp.p: And you bring us this Warre, with your advise, to teach us better purposes!

sp.speaker: Ferrara.
sp.p: I do! lest my councels prevaile not; —I have at a distance profess'd love, and treated long in vaine, which brings me now in Person, to demand Silviana from captivity.

sp.speaker: Urbin.
sp.p: Is it her Person, or my Dukedome? you expect? which invites you to this insolent way of Wooeing?

sp.speaker: Ferrara.
sp.p: 'Tis both, and what both our Parents did designe, when we were Children, in case you left no issue Male.

sp.speaker: Urbin.
sp.p: Silviana is now of Age to please her selfe, and if she desire it; I may treat farther on fit Termes.

sp.speaker: Ferrara.
sp.p: Madam: I have wav'd the common way of wooing, to appeare before you with such an Army, as will justifie my love, great as my selfe! and worthy of your best favours; which I feare your brother does obstruct.

sp.speaker: Silviana.
sp.p: I never heard 'till now, that love, and terror, did inhabit in one brest; fright me you may, but winne me never, by the desolation you have made; a lover by such bloody Characters set off, is what ever I shall flye from.—

sp.speaker: Urbin.
sp.p: Now Sir, does this shew my compulsion for a Nunnery?

sp.speaker: Ferrara.
sp.p: I see she has her lesson perfect, you all comply, to send me home with scornes! yet I must lay before you, the evills of a Towne taken by assault, where fire, and sword, do often without limits sway! which is my last argument, and what I hope; will invite Fernando (who knowes the accidents of Warre,) to mediate such a Peace, as will divert the desolation that may follow.

sp.speaker: Fernando.
sp.p: 'Twill not become me, to advise against the interest of the Prince I serve; — For if my intelligence be true! your Citty of Ferrara, is, or will soon be; in more danger of the Fire, and Sword you mention, then Urbin at present is: —'twere an Infamy irreparable, to suffer the Princess Silviana, to be ravish'd from her brothers Arms, by one she is so much averse to! —such force Sir, can have no pretence to love!

sp.speaker: Ferrara.
sp.p: Are you of that opinion too? —Sir; this confirmes what I have heard, and what in my Camp so freely is discours'd! that your great Generall, is an ambitious Lover; — But if Silviana can submit to so meane approaches! I shall scorne the competition, though in my just anger, I lay this Citty Levell with the Earth.

sp.speaker: Fernando.
sp.p: The meane Generall you slight so much, has never yet presum'd to look with confidence, on the faire Princess Eyes; so farre from daring to pretend, or own that love you so boldly guesse at! that my adresses are yet cloathed in the humble habit of a Servant; to be Silvianas Souldier, I account more honour, then to be Ferraras Duke.—

sp.speaker: Ferrara.
sp.p: This insolence, I shall in few Houres correct.

sp.speaker: Fernando.
sp.p: You judge amiss, and will in few houres finde, this hand can crush Ferrara into Ayre! —

lg.l: —When every drop of Blood in Urbin shed,
Shall be repair'd with a Ferrarians head.

sp.p: — But that I dare not do any thing that looks like ingratitude, for those favours I received, when I was Prisoner in your Campe; though I know the freedome, which you gave was on designe that my inraged Revenge, might open you a way to your pretence for the Faire Princess: —yet benefits receiv'd must be own'd, as they appeare unto the World! and on that account, I can forget these reproaches, thrown out against you know not who! and aske your pardon for my too hasty, harsh reply, and imbrace you as my friend, I, and serve you too! in any way, that will not prejudice my Faith, ingag'd unto this Princess.

sp.speaker: Ferrara.
sp.p: This calme language is more insolent, then your pretence! which I scorne alike; Arme you for defence, lest we give Lawes to your high courages; — Madam, I have no wish so ill, for your contempt of me, but I can sorrow to see you fall so low, as this Souldiers love.

sp.speaker: Fernando.
sp.p: Madam, Thus often urg'd; I beg your leave to challenge this great Prince, to a single Combat in your sight, then judge by our successe, whether Fate approves of my humility, or of his insolent [Pats off his Perriwig.] demands! —see Lodovico, your Rivall is your equall, and my Army now, by my command is at Ferraras gates: —yet I • le take no advantage of my power, (so much more then yours!) but with my single sword, will justify my love to Silviana, does transend all your pretences; and yet before we fight, I once more proffer you my friendship, with a faithfull heart.

sp.speaker: Ferrara.
sp.p: Lorenzo Duke of Florence! who we thought in France: I accept the Combat, and with my Sword will justify my claime, against so brave an Enemy.

sp.speaker: Urbin.
sp.p: This combat I must not allow here; — Lodovico, if you reject the Duke of Florence friendship! and contemne mine: you may retire in safety, but if you please to storme us: we are prepar'd to smile, when you frown most.

sp.speaker: Ferrara.
sp.p: Those frownes you slight so may prove Fatall unto Vrbin.

sp.speaker: Urbin.
sp.p: Why have you made such hazzards, in this disguise Sir.

sp.speaker: Lorenzo.
sp.p: My Fathers sudden death call'd me in hast from France, where I heard of this Warre thretning you: —I shall informe you at more leasure, how I became concern'd for Silviana, which brought me in this disguise to her rescue.

sp.speaker: Urbin.
sp.p: How can I returne this obligation! to a Prince, so much greater then my selfe?

sp.speaker: Lorenzo.
sp.p: One smile from Silviana, will be a full recompence for all my service; on that foundation, I shall raise high hopes, that she approves my love.

sp.speaker: Silviana.
sp.p: Smiles are but slight expressions of a gratefull heart Sir; but if you can build the Noble structure of true love? on such uncertainties! I must consider of so weighty a concerne, before I smile: — Love is a History, so many wayes describ'd, I do not know a harder riddle to expound, then what Love is.

sp.speaker: Lorenzo.
sp.p: Love is indeed a Mystery, full of such strange varieties, that all the World endeavours to fix it, according to their own fancies; so absolutely contradictory in most men, that some think lov's Centrick happinesse, will neer be found; though all pretend to have it. But Madam I am guided by those Rules, that Heav'n directs my worship unto it; — my whole heart is wholly yours, and my unforc'd Marriage is the undoubted Testimony of that truth; all meaner passions which we in gaytye call love, deserves a meaner name; —when I lay my life, and fortune at your Feet, and set my Crown upon your head, I have no better arguments for Love.

sp.speaker: Silviana.
sp.p: Nor I a thought that contradicts what you have said Sir; but dare not rashly answer your desires, lest it suit not with the esteem you have of me.

sp.speaker: Vrbin.
sp.p: No more of this now Silviana, —we must prepare for an assault; — 'tis their last hope! Lorenzo, whom will you appoint for General?

sp.speaker: Lorenzo.
sp.p: Who but Silvianas Souldier! can pretend to that honour Sir; give me your Orders as before.

sp.speaker: Urbin.
sp.p: I obey, — this Paper does order every man his Post, by which you see I have had thoughts of this before.

sp.speaker: Lorenzo.
sp.p: I wish Sir, you would change Florios Post, and give him the charge to guard the Castle, where the Princess may be by him secur'd, from all accidents.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: I thank you for this care, it shall be so.

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: How have I deserv'd this from you Sir?

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.p: You have enough deserv'd my care Florio, and I who know the Duke would account your losse, (next to his Town) the greatest do justify my councell, to have you as safe as honour will allow.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Lorenzo is my friend.

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: But not mine, give me leave then, as I ought, to lead my guards where your selfe fights in person Sir, and I will be content to change my Post.

sp.speaker: Lorenzo.
sp.p: Let it be as he desires Sir; yet I must againe advise you to secure Florio next your selfe, he may prove worthy of all your care, and of your highest favour Sir.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: He is allready so, but you speak in a misterious tone methinks!

sp.speaker: Lorenzo.
sp.p: This assault, I conceive will be their last attempt, and I would gladly prevent a mischiefe that may trouble you; — I know Florios worth now, —get my Arms Luco.

sp.speaker: Luco.
sp.p:
They are ready Sir.
Exeunt Lorenzo, and Luco.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Lorenzos words, and his behavior show,
Something of Florio, more then I yet know.

sp.speaker: 1 Officer.
sp.p: Sir? by the severall noyses in the Campe, 'tis evident they make ready for an assault!

sp.speaker: 2 Officer.
sp.p: We have faire warning to defend our selves, our men are mad to be upon the Wall.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Lead them presently unto their Ports, as great Lorenzo shall direct: 'Twas bravely done to give us warning, and to keep his word, shewes mettle Gentlemen! —where is Prince Lorenzo? and where Florio gone?

sp.speaker: 1 Officer.
sp.p: We met them just now Sir, in the Lobby, which joynes to the Princess Lodgings.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
This is no fit time for complements, —go to your severall commands, I shall be with you suddenly.
Exeunt severally.

div.stage: Enter Lorenzo, Florio with the Princess in her Chamber, the Ladies stand off.

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: Madam Lorenzo beggs the honour to kiss your hand, before the assault begins, that as your Souldier he may fight this day.

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.p: Forenzos merit, justly may expect what I can serve him in.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.p: Madam; I seek not yet a favour beyond your owning of me for your Souldier, —I suppose my actions, and my looks, have better shew'd, then now my language can, how much I love!

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.p: It did not become me to inquire more of you Sir, then you were willing to reveale, yet Florio long since did let fall words, to make me know your quality, did equall mine; and I only wonder'd why you thought not fit to trust me with it.

sp.speaker: Lorenzo.
sp.p: Because I would first know your opinion of me Madam, else my Name, not I, might have wooed for me, and if thus I had been rejected! I might have retyr'd in my disguise, without a pnblique scorne, of being refus'd; which Ferraras prow'd Duke, would have much rejoyc'd at; but if you Madam will so farre honour me, as to allow your Souldier now to kiss your hand, on his hope of future happinesse, I have no doubt of our successe.

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.p: Yes, and shall have my prayers for your Protection.

sp.speaker: Lorenzo.
sp.p: May your happinesse, equall your vertues Madam, I must hasten to the Walls. [He kisses her Hand.]

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: When I have brought the Princess to her lodgings, I will finde out the Duke, and follow you.

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.p: You shall go now Florio, this is no time for Ceremony, my brother is unsafe, when you are from him.—

lg.l: —Heaven guard the Innocent, and only smight,

The bould invadors, of anothers Right.
Exeunt severally.

div.stage: Enter Officers they meet the Duke, who enters at the other Dore.

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.p: The enemy comes on so fast Sir, you can hardly reach your Posts in time.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: I come, —Lorenzo is by this time on the Walls, haste every man unto his Post.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: I was sending for you Florio, —call for my Armes, and bring those I bespoke for Florio too, we will put on our Armes together, and fight neer to one another; —make hast.

div.stage: Enter with Armes for both, they speak as they are Arming, Florios Armes are like those of Pallas.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Let me retyre to the other Room Sir; and put mine on there.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: No, I will have you Arme here, that I may see how my fancy sits you!

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: I feare Sir, that this may look like such a presumption, as I dare not own; — to be thus habitted, will raise a Censure on me.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: On my head let the Censure fall, 'tis my will; —make more haste, lest we be miss'd!

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: I am at your dispose Sir.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Be vigilant, but not over bold; let judgment guide thy [The Duke Armes as he speaks.] courage Florio, that no blow fall in vaine; —reserve thy greatest vigour, 'till some eminent occasion call for such reliefe, as may be worthy of thy hazzard.

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: I shall observe all your directions Sir, my chiefe businesse is, to guard your Person; which if I do not! let the Gods turne from me, when I call on them.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: I shall be safe in thy care I know, —methinks this Coppy, does equall the best Originall, I ever saw presenting Pallas; stand off a while, that now Pigmalion like, I may adore the figure I have made; —though nature bravely had her part perform'd before, yet Art, and fancy I perceive, may such additions give, as will natures best workmanship set off.

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: You make me blush so much Sir, that I shall forget to frown, when I shake my javelin at the Enemy.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: Thy smiles will make that weapon useless, on all that do behold thee; —though we to Dieties alone our Temples build, and shrines set up, if Florio be this day, as prosperous as before! I will for him a Golden Statue make, that after ages our Palladium may extoll, above that unfortunate, fam'd Patroness of Troy.

sp.speaker: Florio.
sp.p: Hark Sir; we may be wish'd for, while we dally here.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Come then, the Victory must sure be ours, —the Enemy will sooner charge a flaming Cloud, then Florio in this dresse!

div.stage: [Enter the Princess; with Phylora and Floremella.]

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.p: The assaults begun Phylora, and my brother not yet there!

sp.speaker: Philora.
sp.p: Lorenzo orders all, and we are sate by his great courage, and his skill in Arms; and yet by this noyse round the Towne, it seems the Walls are every where attach'd.

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.p: 'Tis so Philora, and we are a lost prey, to their greater numbers, the Temple is a fitter place for us.

sp.speaker: Philora.
sp.p: The Gods are every where, and our good wishes are receiv'd as prayers.

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.p: That shout was from the Enemy, now I dispaire!

sp.speaker: Philora.
sp.p: Your feares create mistakes Madam; that shout was neere us, it must be from our own men! that joyfull noyse was victory to us, it can be nothing lesse then victory! where is that courage sled? you had the other day! when I was frighted without cause.

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.p: A Towne thus storm'd! has somewhat more of terror in it, then all the former sallyes had; my heart shrinks now with apprehension, and dismay.

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.p: Madam, The day is ours, the Enemy is quite beaten off, and the great Duke of Florence, with Longino in the head of all our Horse, is now sallyed on the Reare of the Retreating Enemy.

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.p: My thanks to Heav'n for our successe, —the severall noyses from the Walls, created such variety of feares, that I was much dismay'd till you came in.

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.p:
There was argument enough for apprehension Madam▪ for the Wall was gain'd, and the Duke your Brother, sore opprest with multitudes, was beaten off; and fall'n amid'st the press, where his high
courage, rather tyr'd, then vanquish'd, had been lost; if the all conquering Florio, with his guards, had not come timely in to his reliefe; who with such vigour, and such force renew'd the fight, that the amaz'd Enemy, ran headlong from the Walls againe, and struck such terror in the rest of their assailing friends, that altogether sled, in great confusion to their Campe.

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.p: All this I do rejoyce at; but methinks those shouts of joy, are chang'd into a dismall silence on the suddaine! why do not the streets ring, with acclamations for our Victory? good Heav'n preserve the Duke, I have some apprehension that he may be hurt.

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.p: No hurt appear'd at my departure, only Florio was beaten down, by an accidentall shot, at randome from the slying Enemie; after which, I saw him stand; though but weakly.

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.p: Let us retyre Phylora, till my brother does arive.

div.stage: Enter the Duke with others his Shirt bloody, bearing in Florio, neere dead, they set him in a Chayre, with Pedro, helping to dresse him.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: A Surgeon, a Surgeon, my Dukedome for a Surgeon! —gently, gently set him downe, Florios death strikes deep! friendship I finde takes faster hold on hearts then love! —poore youth, he slew quick as lightning to my rescue, and as I fell, (oppress'd by Multitudes;) he scatter'd them like frighted Birds, at an approaching storme; —and thus by saving me, has lost himselfe; by an accidentall shot from the beaten flying Enemy! —but sure the Gods will not permit, that so great vertue from the World be taine, lest offended Nature into its first Chaos shrinke.—

lg.l: —Through suddaine horror, and a just disdaine,
To hold the World up, after Florio slaine.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Now Surgeon shew your skill, while I powre out my prayers to Heav'n for his recovery. [He leanes against the Wall and weeps.]

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Oh Silviana! I am undone, —Florio is slaine, friendship is ravish • d from the earth! and all my joyes sled with it! —speak Surgeon does he live?

sp.speaker: Surgeon.
sp.p: Here is life Sir, but little hope of long continuance, unlesse what we apply, do suddenly shew better signes.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: By what unknown crymes have I provok'd Heav'n? when vertue is thus punish'd! thus to shew me Paradice, and cast me into Hell, is more then Nature can submit to, and not repine.

div.stage: Enter Lorenzo, and Longino with the Duke of Ferrara prisoner, and his Officers prisoners.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: We bring you joy Sir; and a full viory, with this great prisoner.

sp.speaker: Urbin.
sp.p: Here is no roome for joy Lorenzo, I am destroy'd by victory! see where Death in Triumph sits! prowder of that prey, then for all the Heroes in past Ages fall'n.

sp.speaker: Lorenzo.
sp.p: Ha! Florio slaine! how could this happen after I was gone! and the day wonne! — I may now curse my selfe, for not preventing this, —how short are those glittering joyes we so much labour for! when all the glories we have gain'd, are in a moment turn'd into heart breaking griefes! —I am undone too!

sp.speaker: Urbin.
Lorenzo.
sp.p: Alas Sir, your sorrowes will go higher yet! when you know who Florio is! —I have a greater losse in Florio, then you discerne, or can pretend to! which will no longer now be hid: —hold Surgeon, —and let the Ladies help to undresse her, she is a Lady, and my neer relation Sir, who loves you more, then you love Florio.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: A Woman Lorenzo! Oh do not mock me with a hope to make this losse beyond Mortallity to beare: a Woman! let me gaze on this dying wonder; 'till my Eyes drop out, —(and lov's me, as I do Florio!) that is impossible! —this is a fatall blow indeed! —Oh Sister! now your help! —Surgeon if she live, thou shalt be, whatever I can make thee great: work, worke, apply the rarest remedies, —some help from Heav'n, or I am lost! a Woman! Florio a Woman! and in my rescue dye! and love me too! Oh this is much, too much to know, and to outlive. [He lies on the ground.]

sp.speaker: Surgeon.
sp.p: Pray Sir, a little patience, her Eyes have some small motion now, —Ladies your help is usefull here.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Gently deere Silviana, kind Philora gently, every touch she suffers, grates on my heart; —Florio thy love was not well mannag'd; — the more I think, the more I am amaz'd! — give her life, or strike me dead! a Woman!

sp.speaker: Lorenzo.
sp.p: I Sir, a Woman, and of Noblest birth!

div.stage: [The Duke kneels and holds her Hand.]

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: I value not her birth, 'tis Vertue thus adorn'd, that I adore! [He kneeles and hold her head.] — blest figure of those shapes which do inhabit Heav'n, — she looks up Silviana! and may live! runne good Alphonso, runne.

sp.speaker: Alphonso.
sp.p: Whither Sir; and why!

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
Fetch my Mothers Diadem, and Royall Robe, flye now Alphonso
Exit Alpho: flye! — I have a thousand thoughts at once; what Triumphs I will make, what Trophies raise! if my Faire Saint survive; — but if she dye! these glitring fancies will be drench'd in Blood, Lorenzo! I will swimme in blood, to overtake her Ghost, when ever she departs.

sp.speaker: Surgeon.
sp.p: Now she is drest, pray give her leave to rest a little.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.p: My Prophetique soule foresaw some mighty evill towards, when I desir'd that Florio might not fight to day.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: One word of Woman, had prevented all; —to conceale her Sex Lorenzo, was as cruell, as unkinde; that known; she had been safe, and I most happy.

sp.speaker: Lorenzo.
sp.p: I now wish that I had broke my Oath to Celestina, and run all hazzards by it.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Now I understand those her misterious vow's, so often made to me; which I then took for gratitude; —how blinde was love! —rather how powerfull is thy Deity, Oh love! what mighty things do those by thee inspir'd produce? when the weak hands of this soft sex, can raise such Emulation in the bravest men! —and can outdoe us too! in what they undertake: —how strangely dull was I, that did not all this while by sympathetick Love, her Sex discerne, through this disguise?

div.stage: Enter Alphonso with Crowne and Robes, the Duke puts them on Florio as he slumbers.

sp.speaker: Duke.

lg.l: Our victory does yet so dismall show,
No ruine could have caus'd a greater woe.

sp.p: —My heart, my heart Lorenzo, shrinks away so fast, that I shall fall; —how dull were we Silviana? to think such beauty could belong to man! [Leanes on Alphonso.]

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.p: Or such courage be in Woman found!

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Lorenzo, I am distracted with so many wonders breaking out at once! that my shatred heart, can yet finde no joy to entertaine so great a Guest as you; nor inquire what accident did bring you hither?

sp.speaker: Lorenzo:
sp.p: Fame of Silvianas Vertues, brought me hither Sir; where I unlook'd for, met, poore Celestina, my unhappy Cousin, who —

lg.l: —Did, from her Fathers rigid kindnesse flye,
Led by her starres, to this sad Destiny.

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.l: Did ever any Age such mischiefe know?
Or two such courages such sorrow show?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: If Celestina live? Urbin shall shine in Triumphs, to speak Lorenzos welcome: —but if she Dye, I have no life that I can call a minute mine; I must not, will not, cannot survive so great a losse!

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.p: She wakes, she wakes! and looks up cheerfull.

div.stage: [The Duke kneels and holds her hand.]

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Flye to the Temples, and rich insence burne, proclaime a publique Feast throughout the Towne; let all the holy Orders in Procession go, make solemne vow's to Heav'n, for Celestinas life!

lg.l: —Now let the Citty, there Devotions pay,
For Victory; and keep this Holliday!

sp.speaker: Celestina.
sp.p: Is this a vision? or is it reall what I see? these Robes I understand not, —the Duke kneeling! the Princess, and Lorenzo weeping! — I do either dreame! or I am dead! — why all this to me?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: To the Dutchess of URBIN, this is due; Heav'n Celestina has heard my prayers, and will I hope, preserve your life, to raise my dispairing soule, above the World, if you consent? Triumphant love, with such resplendant Rayes adorn'd, will change these sullen Clouds, into a glorious shine, throughout my Land; and every heart rejoyce at our Felicities.

sp.speaker: Celestina.
sp.p: Lorenzo then, has made himselfe, and me known to you Sir; —which does beget such shame, as makes my soule retyre, from what it most joyes in: —can you value such a counterfeit as I?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Can I be thankfull! for the greatest blessing, men have on Earth? all had been well, if Lorenzo had declar'd you sooner!

sp.speaker: Celestina.
sp.p: My businesse was to dye unknown, lest my disguise, should raise a scandall on my Name for ever! Lorenzo knew me not till yesterday.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: This disguise Celestina, has by mistakes brought all this evill on us; let us no more mention it; but implore Heav'n for your recovery.

sp.speaker: Lorenzo.
sp.p: How will you dispose of your great prisoner Sir.

sp.speaker: Urbin.
sp.p: As my friend, now Celestina lives! these Arms shall be your only bonds, while you are with us; — I owe all the felicities I now [to Ferrara] enjoy, to you Sir, —I had neer seen Florio, nor found Lorenzo here, without this Warre: And if Lodovico can submit? to what the Gods have thus decree'd; we may be ever friends; but I shall impose no Rules for you to follow, who are as free here, as at Ferrara; for I intend a Jubilee to all, who will participate my joyes.

sp.speaker: Lodovico.
sp.p: Though my success, affords no argument for joy, I can acknowledg your civilities; and must submit unto those powers, who order our designes, according to their wills, not ours.

sp.speaker: Lorenzo.
sp.p: I have a heart to serve Lodovico too; if it may be receiv'd!

sp.speaker: Lodovico.
sp.p: Since victory has decided our contest, 'twere uselesse to hold up such animosity, as can afford no remedy; I shall therefore strive to regulate my heart, unto my Fortune.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Wee must now begg your pardon Sir, and yours Silviana, our high transports, for these strange accident, have too long diverted our respects for you Sir.

sp.speaker: Lorenzo.
sp.p: If Silviana do yet dare to own me? little Ceremony wil be needfull here.

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.p: If I had not long since seen through your disguise! somewhat of greater worth, then your low Equipage allow'd; you had not found so quick a passage to my heart.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: 'Tis my part to joyne your hands, now you avow your hearts united: I wish you as much joy Sir, as you have help'd me to, by Celestinas Love.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.p: I can have none beyond, what I rejoyce to see you have Sir.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: How is it Celestina? does your heart with your health comply? to make me happy?

sp.speaker: Celestina.
sp.p: Yes Sir, now all my doubts are vanish'd, I have time to look back on my dispaires, with pleasure; and to rejoyce, and wonder at your love! so much beyond my merit, or my hope!

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Though habits sexes often may devide,
They could not Celestinas vertues hide;
VVhich gave such Lustre to young Florios name,
It rais • d my wonder! and begot this • lame.
Which ever must admire that blest disguise,
When Florio shew'd me Celestinas Eyes.
Thus mighty Love Triumph'd, in friendship drest,
Though his Magnetick Vertue, seem'd supprest.

div.head: THE EPILOGVE To the SIEGE of VRBIN.
div.l: EPILOGUES we know, if well fitted! may
Either excuse, or else set off the Play!
But our Fantastick Author does believe,
His Doublet may be wor'ne without a sleeve!
He will no Epilogue allow; the Pit
He sayes, of late, hath surfeted of Wit;
[poynts to the Pit.] And therefore has this new rigg'd Pinnace Launc'd
Into these Deeps; and now too farre advanc'd
Without a Rudder: Yet if friends! you may
With gentle Gales this guidlesse Barke convey
Through all its dangers, to the wished Port;
And so prove Pilots of the noblest sort.

div.p: OXFORD, Printed for the Author, and are to be sold by Ric: Davis, 1666.

list.item: Selindra, A great Lady Attending Ordella, and supposed Daughter of Periander; but is Astella, Princess of Hungary.
Periander, A great Lord of Ciprus.
Trebello, King of Hungary. These appear not.
Barzanes, his Eldest Son. These appear not.

div.head: SCENE Is the Emperors Palace at Bizantium.
The FIRST ACT.
div.stage: Enter two Lords, Antenor and Gillon.

sp.speaker: Ante:
sp.p: THis Rumor through the Town of Prince Phillocles being Crowned King of Hungary is beyond cregit!

sp.speaker: Gillon:
sp.p: Who is Author of this discourse?

sp.speaker: Ante:
sp.p: It has no Author, a Packet to the Emperor is brought by the common Post, who only said, the last Post told him so.

sp.speaker: Gillon:
sp.p: And that last post, might hear it from another; — What does the Emperor declare?

sp.speaker: Ante:
sp.p: We shall know now, his Letters are in his hand.

div.stage: Enter Lascares Emperor of Greece, with Cecropius, Cleonell, and Guards.

sp.speaker: Empe:
sp.p: Have you yet Learnt Cecropius, from whence this Rumour comes concerning Hungary?

sp.speaker: Cecro:
sp.p: I can by no means find the Author Sir; yet the whole Town is full of it, 'tis in all mens mouths that Prince Phillocles is Crown'd King of Hungary, yet none know why they say it?

sp.speaker: Emp:
sp.p: It cannot be, these Letters are but three dayes old, in which Antillacus only mentions Phillocles return'd to Belgrade, having chased the Germanes home: —

div.stage: Enter the Princess Ordella, Selindra, and Ladies to them.

sp.speaker: Emp:
sp.p:
Daughter, I sent for you to partake the Newes these Letters bring; they speak Phillocles his Victories over the bold Germanes,
by which we gather, he will be shortly here; —We will welcome his returne Ordella, with a solemne Triumph, to raise his great thoughts to higher Actions; —To this end I sent for you, to think of some new way to entertain the Princess Astella, who no doubt your Brother will bring with him.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: Sir, I am so pleas'd to hear my Brother's well; I cannot yet enjoy his Conquest.

sp.speaker: Emp:
sp.p: Cecropius, be it your care to see these Triumphs ordered for Phillocles, as they were for me, when I return'd Victorious out of Asia; And Cleonel thy charge is to Summon all our Young Nobility, unto a Royal Turnament, and be thy self the Glory of our Court.

sp.speaker: Cle:
sp.p: You make me blush Sir.

sp.speaker: Cecro:
sp.p: It shall be as you direct Sir; but how soon does the Prince write his motion will be this way?

sp.speaker: Emp:
sp.p: My Letters are from our General Antillachus in hast; who by the next, doth promise a full relation.

sp.speaker: Or:
sp.p: Have you no Letters from my Brother Sir?

sp.speaker: Empe:
sp.l: Not yet Ordella; which I much wonder at?
—What newes Armanthus?

sp.speaker: Arman:
sp.p: Sir, the Prince sent me before, to give you notice of his approach.

sp.speaker: Emp:
sp.p: His approach! how near?

sp.speaker: Arman:
sp.p: He is about a League behind Sir.

sp.speaker: Emp:
sp.p: Is this habit, and thy sad looks, the signes of Victory? are Phillocles and you alone return'd? Is all lost Armanthus?

sp.speaker: Arman:
sp.p: Your Army is safe Sir, the Germanes have quitted Hungary as you have heard, and that Crown also has been offred unto Phillocles.

sp.speaker: Emp:
sp.p: And by him received I hear; why then is this sad shew? why such sorrowes in thy face? while we were ordering Triumps to receive Phillocles, thou hast surpriz'd us with such sadness, as becomes ruined States onely.

sp.speaker: Arman:
sp.p: 'Tis for no lesse a losse I mourn Sir, for by your Victories, so sad a fate is befallen Hungary, that all Noble Hearts will feel some sorrow for it, though they merrited no less!

sp.speaker: Emp:
sp.p: Make me know it.

sp.speaker: Arman:
sp.p: When we had freed Hungary from the Germane Warre, and while the brave Prince Pollinesso, with Phillocles was Conquering, and returning from the Germane Confines back to Belgrade, the old King Trebellio, and his Eldest Son Barzanes, repented the Conditions made with your Majesty, for the re-delivery of Moldavia; they forgot the benefit received by our Grecian Swords, and prepare to send home Phillocles, loaden with Scorns, instead of Trophies.

sp.speaker: Emp:
sp.p: Strange insolence! and as high a perjury as ever provok'd Heaven! what followed! how did Pollinesso bear himself?

sp.speaker: Arman:
