sp.p: Cecropius you shall have Justice; — go you Antenor, and command the Provost of the City that he seize Selindra, and her fellow Murtherers, let them be all close Prisoners in the black Tower; by to morrow this time, shall their bloods be shed, as they shed Cleonels.

sp.speaker: Ordel:
sp.p: Did you say Selindra should be Prisoner Sir.

sp.speaker: Emp:
sp.p: I did.

sp.speaker: Ordel:
sp.p: Good Sir, call back Antenor till you have heard me speak.

sp.speaker: Emp:
sp.p: I may not Ordella.

sp.speaker: Ordel:
sp.p: Who can forbid you to be Merciful? and just? you break the Lawes of Hospitality in this; Selindra is a stranger, she is innocent, and cannot suffer justly; Cleonel was full of horrid guilt, and was cut off by a just hand; —the Travellers too, have saved Phillocles his life; good Sir, let not Cecropius malice, perswade you to do, what you will blush to think on after.

sp.speaker: Emp:
sp.p: They shall have Justice, and a Legal Tryall.

sp.speaker: Ordel:
sp.p: Oh Sir! where is your wonted mercy? whither is that goodnesse fled? how have I lost your favour? that cannot with my Tears, nor Prayers prevale on your mistaken anger.

sp.speaker: Phill:
sp.p: Is it your Majesties Command, that Selindra should be a Prisoner?

sp.speaker: Emp:
sp.p: Must I aske your leave?

sp.speaker: Phil:
sp.p: Though not my leave Sir, I cannot chuse but wonder at such rigour!

sp.speaker: Emp:
sp.p: You have leave to wonder on.

sp.speaker: Phill:
sp.p: Thus low Sir, I do humbly beg Selindra's Inlargement, and an equall Tryal for those that rescued us; — [He kneels.]

sp.speaker: Emp:
sp.p: Selindra as chief accessary must abide the Sentence of the Law, in this case of Cleonel: —Phillocles thy mean Love has drown'd all my Favours, and Eclip'st all thy former actions; from this time I shall study to forget thee, unlesse thou wilt forget Selindra, and lead the Army to relieve Astella.

sp.speaker: Phill:
sp.p: I shall obey you Sir in this, and all things else, so you will be pleas'd to send Selindra safe to Ciprus, and set those innocent men free, that saved my life.

sp.speaker: Emp:
sp.p: Degenerate fool, I shall cure this disease in thee; Cecropius send presently for the Judges, Command them by virtue of this my Signet, to put the Lawes in present Execution, upon thy Sons Murtherers; let the rigour of the Law passe on them all.

sp.speaker: Phil:
sp.p: Ye Gods, to what purpose are men innocent? why is virtue prays'd, and taught us? —Good Sir, consider how you do murther these innocents, with a shew of Law, and a pretence of Justice.

sp.speaker: Emp:
sp.p: How dare you talke thus?

sp.speaker: Phil:
sp.p: You make me desperate Sir.

sp.speaker: Emp:
sp.p: Do not raise my temper higher, lest I cut thee off, as if thou wer't no part of me; — they shall dye.

sp.speaker: Phill:
sp.p: Had the Gods so pleas'd, I wish my self the meanest of your Subject, for I am now a slave unto your passions, and must inherit the curse that's due to all your guilts, such as I shake to think on; 'Tis you Sir, that have murthered Cleonel, 'twas your poyson that Selindra fled from; by your confining me, you gave Cecropius first, and Cleonel next, the power to become Ravishers; pray let the Law take notice of this! — It may free innocent persons.

sp.speaker: Emp:
sp.p: Who am I? Is this Gallant my Son, or my Soveraigne?

sp.speaker: Phil:
sp.p: Sir I do see fire, and fury in your Eyes, and am prepar'd to meet it, 'tis better to dye with those are Noble, then to live thus neglected; by my hand two of Cleonels men fell, 'tis I am guilty of that sin of rescuing Selindra from a Rape: let your Justice, and your Lawes, grow famous by my blood, 'twill please Cecropius well; by all our Gods I▪le not out-live those innocents.

sp.speaker: Emp:
sp.p: Tis fit to take thee at thy word.

div.stage: The Emperor Draws and Runs at Phillocles to kill him, Ordella steps between.

sp.speaker: Phil:
sp.p: It will become your own hand best.

sp.speaker: Ordel:
sp.p: Have you another Son Sir, when you have slain my Brother?

sp.speaker: Emper:
sp.p: Antenor, call in my Guard, and carry Phillocles to the New Castle; see that he be safe, and close there, as you will answer it with your life; —I shall not trust you in the Army now Sir.

sp.speaker: Ordel:
sp.p: Pray Sir re-call this severe command, my Brother has no danger in him, you saw he did not avoid death, when your hand offer'd it.

sp.speaker: Emp:
sp.p: Antenor, I will be obeyed; —by Heaven he dyes that dares dispute my Will.

sp.speaker: Phill:
sp.p: If I go to Prison? Selindra dyes, there is none can help her, [He kneels.] and then, I shall have time hereafter, to lament her sad fate; Sir, I aske your pardon for the harsh words I utter'd, I did believe those truths might touch you, and move compassion towards those you threaten so much rigour too: but I now see your anger has decreed them dead, and that you have the same thought for me; my last sute is, that since we may not live, we may dye together: I shall submit to any kind of Death Sir; But I have vowed to be no more confin'd.

sp.speaker: Emp:
sp.p: You of the Guard seize on him.

div.stage: [As the Guard comes toward him he draws.]

sp.speaker: Phil:
sp.p: Against Imprisonment, I shall endeavour what I can; command my death Sir, and I will welcome it.

sp.speaker: Emp:
sp.p: Kill him; —Kill the Traytor; —dares none stirre to do it? Is my breath grown so weak? Ile try my own strength then.

div.stage: The Emperor snatches a Partizan from one of the Guard, and wounds Phillocles in the breast slightly, Phillocles holding down his Sword opens his arms and receives the wound, they search his wound, set him in a Chair, while the Emperor stands amaz'd at what he had done.

sp.speaker: Ordell.
sp.p: Oh, my Brother's slain! how cruel, and unnaturall a deed is this?

sp.speaker: Cecro:
sp.p: The Surgeons say the Chiefe prisoner will not Live till Morning; I beg Sir, that the sentence may passe on the rest.

div.stage: The Emperor gives Cecropius no answer, only points to Phillocles, lets fall the Partizan till then in his hand, and Exit with Cecropius.

sp.speaker: Antil:
sp.p: 'Twas well the Emperors age did not permit his force to act his will, the wound has not past the bone Madam, 'tis but a slight cut in the flesh.

sp.speaker: Arman:
sp.p: 'Tis time that you hasten to the Army, for while Cecropius holds his power, you cannot be safe here.

sp.speaker: Ordell:
sp.p: He advises well Brother, untill my Father be dispossest of this evill spirit that reignes in him, I wish you away too.

sp.speaker: Phil:
sp.p: I think it must be so; the Souldiers I hope have not forgot their love to me; —My Dear Sister, pray will you ore-take my Father lest in this sit he slay all our Friends; say that Selindra did sly willingly with Cleonel, and that she regards not my Love, say any thing to gaine a little time, untill I may do something to relieve them.

sp.speaker: Ordel:
sp.p: I shall do my best: —

div.stage: Ordella at the Door meets the Emperor with Selindra in his hand, and Pollidor led in, he delivers Selindra to Ordella, and points to them to set Pollidor by Phillocles, then goes out with Cecropius and Servants.

sp.speaker: Ordell:
sp.p: What means my Father by this dumb shew?

sp.speaker: Polli:
sp.p: Where are we now Tenedor?

sp.speaker: Tene:
sp.p: Truly Sir, I know not, but I see Friends here.

sp.speaker: Polli:
sp.p: Who are they?

sp.speaker: Tene:
sp.p: Those that brought you in, were the Emperor, and Cecropius; you know Prince Phillocles, that whispers with Selindra, that other sure is the Princess Ordella.

sp.speaker: Polli:
sp.p: Is that the Princess Ordella?

sp.speaker: Phill:
sp.p: Your presence Madam gives me strength, and your kind looks, give life unto my drooping spirits.

sp.speaker: Selin:
sp.p: How miserable am I Sir, that am the occasion of all these evils.

sp.speaker: Phil:
sp.p: Your own sufferings are the onely evills to be lamented, I could curse my self, that brings such troubles on you; —but Madam we forget to comfort this Gallant man, by whose Sword we enjoy our Lives: —Sir, can you pardon me that undertook so much, and can so little serve you?

sp.speaker: Polli:
sp.p: It was an injury Sir, to think I would receive my life, ransom'd by your death.

sp.speaker: Phill:
sp.p: By my wound Pollidor, I have appeas'd my Fathers Rage; by thy wounds Selindra Lives, and through all these Clouds, I see the Tempest ceasing; —cannot Selindra speak to him?

sp.speaker: Selin:
sp.p: I have a heart as full of Gratitude as yours Sir, but not yet any means to shew it; I shall make it my businesse to serve him.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Has my Dear Sister no complement for Pollidor? by whose valour she enjoyes Selindra, and me.

sp.speaker: Ordel:
sp.p: Yes Phillocles, I am studying how to expresse it, for you two have left nothing for me to say: Sir, I can only thank you o're again for my Brothers, and my Friends preservation, by which you have obliged me, and the whole Empire, and do deserve some publique Honour, and high Recompence.

sp.speaker: Polli:
sp.p: What honour, or what recompence can outweigh this you now heap on me? Madam, if what I have done, be a service that you will own, I have no wish beyond it; I shall ever on this day keep a solemn Feast unto the Gods, that did direct my course that way, and gave me power to become as happy here, as in Elizium.

sp.speaker: Phill:
sp.p: Let those Lodgings next to mime, be made ready for Pollidor, I will not trust him farther from me; — Antillacus, go you with as little noyse as may be to the Army, and let the Souldiers know, that I will suddainly be with them; some lead out Pollidor.

sp.speaker: Cecro:
sp.p: 'Twas not revenge, for Cleonel, made me presse your Majesty to do Justice on his Murtherers, but to cut off Selindra, by which Phillocles might have no hindrance to gain Astella; —But Sir, since you have freed the Prisoners, and are content, the Prince shall marry Selindra, I have done; if you Sir, can lay by all thoughts of Astella; and that Crown, I shall soon forget a private losse.

sp.speaker: Emp:
sp.p: I must laugh Cecropius to see how thou art abus'd by my feigned shew of kindnesse, which I only did, to heal the wound I gave; had I another Son, by whom I might gaine Hungary, Phillocles had found my Force, answerable to my Anger; but I confesse I did relent, upon a suddain thought, which made me strike so feebly at him, for now to loose Phillocles, were to throw Hungary away, and to destroy Selindra, were by another kind of stroak to destroy Phillocles.

sp.speaker: Cecro:
sp.p: What other way have you Sir? that I cannot yet fancy.

sp.speaker: Emp:
sp.p: A sure one Cecropius, away that cannot faile, I will give loose reins to my Sons Love, let him run on, and Joy in his beloved Selindra, whose sweets once had, and his young appetite allayed, (as most violent passions soonest are) then 'twill be best to take away Selindra by a Poyson; then it may be done without suspition, while I urge on the Marriage, joyne in all the Nuptiall Jollities, and put on such pleasing looks, as shall make thee doubt my purpose, though thou knowest my heart.

sp.speaker: Cecro:
sp.p: I see not yet how this can get Astella, or that Crown.

sp.speaker: Emp:
sp.p: Thou art grown so dull of late, that thou seest nothing; while this joy lasts, Astella may be found, and then Selindra dying, what can hinder Phillocles from getting Astella?

sp.speaker: Cecro:
sp.p: I do submit Sir, and must applaud your purpose, 'tis a design I do confesse, much above my reach, and the first mischief I have come short in. Exeuut ambo.

div.stage: Pollidor seen in his Chamber, Enter to him Phillocles and Ordella, and Selindra, the servants go off.

sp.speaker: Phil:
sp.p: You look chearfully to day Pollidor, we may hope to see you abroad shortly.

sp.speaker: Polli:
sp.p: I believe I might venture now Sir, though my Surgeons be not of my mind; but Sir, how do you find the good old Emperor dispos'd.

sp.speaker: Phil:
sp.p: I like not my Fathers smiles Pollidor, his suddain starts into such extreams, make me apprehend more danger in his kindnesse, then his rage; so that to prevent all further evils, I have a purpose to repaire unto the Army; and 'tis Ordella's wish, as well as mine, that Selindra would trust her self with me there.

sp.speaker: Polli:
sp.p: That may secure you both, but will not Selindra's honour suffer?

sp.speaker: Ordel:
sp.p: Now that Selindra's interest, and his are become one, I see no reason she should fear to go, nor indeed any scruple why their Marriage may not be privatly, and presently dispatch'd, for while the businesse lingers thus, they give hopes to such Endeavours as would divert it, and do runne daily hazzards, by staying here.

sp.speaker: Phillo:
sp.p: Ordella argues what my soul wishes, but Selindra's looks do not consent to make me so soon happy.

sp.speaker: Selin:
sp.p: Sir, my loooks do be-lye my heart, if they shew ought that would delay a happinesse to you, for I have none beyond yours: — But Sir, above all other reasons, Pollidor (not being yet able to attend you) if he be left behind, will hardly escape Cecropius's fury?

sp.speaker: Phil:
sp.p: Most true Selindra, he will be in danger, I shall therefore attend his recovery; without him I will not move; nor will I put a thought in act without thy Councel.

sp.speaker: Ordel:
sp.p: You have both said well, but in my judgment, this is no fit time for such Complements, when your lives are daily sought.

sp.speaker: Polli:
sp.p: If you be resolv'd to attend my recovery, I shall propose a sudden fancy of mine, to that purpose, which may secure us:

sp.speaker: Phill:
sp.p: Speak it Pollidor.

sp.speaker: Polli:
sp.p: Suppose Selindra do ask the Princess leave to return to Cyprus, and give out that she only expects, her Fathers coming to convey her thither. —Sir, you may court Selindra publikely while she stayes, and she seem to neglect your love, and put on a shew of kindnesse unto me, as in gratitude for my hazzards in her redemption, I will also counterfeit affection to Selindra, and give out, that I am of better quality then I seem: This Sir, if well manag'd, will be ground enough, to deceive their best Spies, and for some time secure us all.

sp.speaker: Phillocles.
sp.p: I approve your thought Pollidor, and if Selindra can undertake her part, doubt not me, I'le put on such a seeming jealousie, as shall puzzle the old Fox Cecropius himself.

sp.speaker: Selindra.
sp.p: I shall easily observe my directions, and soon learn to be civil to a man, I owe so much to!

sp.speaker: Phillo:
sp.p: Come Ordella, while they practise love, we will reconcile us to the Emperor, and try to bring him on a present visit to Pollidor, before this sit of his good nature leave him.

sp.speaker: Ordel:
sp.p: Selindra we must find you sitting in a more familiar way with Pollidor, then ordinary conversation does allow.

sp.speaker: Selindra.
sp.p: I shall obey you Madam: — Now they are gone, we may enjoy our selves, this happy design of yours, will afford us many houres of freedome.

sp.speaker: Pollidor.
sp.p: My soul is joyed to look on thee Astella!

sp.speaker: Selin:
sp.p: And my happinesse too great to be exprest by words! that you live! makes this Earth a Paradice to me; my heart can scarce make roome for Phillocles, it is so full of Pollinesso!

sp.speaker: Polli:
sp.p: I am all thine Astella.

div.stage: [Enter to them Tenedor, Tecknor, and others.]

sp.speaker: Tenedor.
sp.p: Is it time Sir, that you retir'd to rest, you spend your spirits, by so much discourse, which does retard your cure.

sp.speaker: Teck:
sp.p: You should neglect no means Sir, for your recovery, lest by a long stay here, some accident unlook'd for, may make you known.

sp.speaker: Tenedor.
sp.p: I wonder Phillocles does not call to mind that he has seen you.

sp.speaker: Pollidor.
sp.p: He believes me dead, as all others do; but I shall observe the best rules for my recovery however: — Now Astella we have time to hear how you were conveyed from Belgrade, pray make me know how you came hither!

sp.speaker: Selin:
sp.p: That same night that you departed to the Army, and our first Embassadors went towards Greece, to implore Lascares's aid against the Germanes, I was by my Fathers own hand deliver'd unto Periander, whom I was to call Father; and by him was brought to Ciprus, where the Plague then raging, he transports me with his Family to this Town.

sp.speaker: Pollidor.
sp.p: How came you into the Court then?

sp.speaker: Selin:
sp.p: On the first Feast-day, I went with Periander to the Temple, that I might see the Emperor, and the Printess Ordella, where the Princess casting her Eyes on me, found mine so fixed on her, that I could not remove them, but blush'd, and still look'd on her; by what power led, I know not; but she took a fancy to have me live with her, which Periander durst shew no dislike to: thus was I, to my great joy, call'd to Court, where I became a Companion to the Princess: within a short time Cleonel had affection for me, which did not free me from old Cecropius dotage: of which, with Prince Phillocles his worthy love, you shall know hereafter, for I have now held you too long from your repose.

sp.speaker: Pollidor.
sp.p: Dearest Astella thy words are balsome to my wounds.

div.stage: Enter Emperor, Phillocles, Ordella, Cecropius, and Traine, and see them Embracing.

sp.speaker: Phillocles.
sp.p: Your Majesty will not think this honour too much for Pollidor, when you shall know he is of better quality then he seems; — ha! what do I see? [They embrace and rise disturb'd.]

sp.speaker: Emp:
sp.p: That which should teach thee to have nobler thoughts Philloces, think on this surprize.

sp.speaker: Phil:
sp.p: How they are disturb'd!

sp.speaker: Ordel:
sp.p: They do it rarely well. [aside.]

sp.speaker: Emp:
sp.p: Sir, I am now come to excuse the imprisonment you had, and to give you thanks for my sons life; I shall now endeavour to recompence your merit, rather then trouble you with words.

sp.speaker: Poll:
sp.p: Great Sir, this honour, with the many other favours I receiv'd, do shame me to think that you allow me a merrit I cannot own, but if the Gods do give me life, my onely businesse shall be to seek occasions to serve you and yours.

sp.speaker: Emp:
sp.p: I shall contribute what I can to your health, and will please my selfe, with the expectation of great things from you.

div.stage: While they talk, the Emperor observes Phillocles courting Selindra, and she neglecting him; the Emperor observes Pollidor to be troubled at their Courtship, and is pleased at it.

sp.speaker: Poll:
sp.p: Sir, you oblige me beyond words, to utter my sense of your favours.

sp.speaker: Emp:
sp.p: My purpose is to give you a kind welcome, and a respect suitable to your worth, and quality: —fair Maid, I know not well how [He goes to Selindra.] to frame my discourse to you, whom I have so ill treated; but I shall no more disturb your joyes, I do now make it my suit, that you will defer your return to Ciprus, I shall lay my commands on Ordella, to deny you her consent to go.

sp.speaker: Selin:
sp.p: Sir, The favours and honours I have received here, are farre beyond the ills you mention; and my happinesse such, in the Princesse Ordella's love, that I lament the thoughts of my departure, but when I consider the mischiefes past, and foresee worse like to follow, 'twere madnesse not to fly them; when my Father is return'd, I shall renew my suit, to have the Princess leave, to leave this place, and until then, make it my care, to tend this hurt man, my redeemer! to whom I owe my life and honour!

sp.speaker: Emp:
sp.p:
Selindra, if I can adde any thing unto thy happinesse, I shall do it gladly, for thou art something more, then ever I have found in Woman.
Exeunt Emperor and Cecropius.

sp.speaker: Phill:
sp.p: What thanks do we owe Pollidor for this disguise! it takes Ordella, beyond our hopes; did you observe how my Father eyed us, while he talked to Pollidor?

sp.speaker: Ordella.
sp.p: Yes, and do believe Cecropius and he are gone to compare their notes, for that Fox was very vigilant.

sp.speaker: Phill:
sp.p: Selindra, let us enjoy this blest minute.

div.stage: Phillocles leads Selindra to the Couch, and Ordella goes to Pollidor.

sp.speaker: Ordel:
sp.p:
Sir, While the two Lovers whisper, pray oblige me with the knowledge of the occasion of your coming into these parts, by which we have received so great an obligation; and if you please? to passe this
time with the relation of your own story, unlesse with your selfe, you would conceale it.

sp.speaker: Poll:
sp.p: Madam, My story is not worthy your eares, nor my self this honour: —yet I have a story, —such as will make me blush to utter, though no crime do belong to it: —nor am I what I seem, and yet not fit to appear other, —but Madam, your commands are too high honours to be neglected, my own resolutions shall give way, and my nearest concernes submit to your will.

sp.speaker: Ord:
sp.p: I perceive you are disturb'd at my curiosity to know, what I believe you would conceal; it may be you have vowed not to discover; truly Sir, for want of what to say, I onely said it.

sp.speaker: Poll:
sp.p: Madam, I was surpriz'd by your approach, which made my tongue appeare lesse ready then my heart to obey you; your commands, Madam, are sufficient to dissolve any vowes of mine, and since you will vouchsafe to hear, I shall relate.

sp.speaker: Phill:
sp.p: How are you Sir? Methinks your Eyes do shew some anguish in your wounds, do we not trouble you?

div.stage: Here Phillocles and Selindra interrupt Pollidor, which puts him into some passion, for he now began to love Ordella.

sp.speaker: Ord:
sp.p: We have done ill to stay thus long, Selindra 'tis your fault, you should have directed better.

sp.speaker: Poll:
sp.p: No Madam, my houre to rest is not so precisely to be kept, nor have I any pains upon me, as the Prince thinks; my wounds heal the faster for your company.

sp.speaker: Ord:
sp.p: You are civil Sir.

sp.speaker: Poll:
sp.p: Madam, the Prince's kindnesse, and his care, is not at this time necessary: —pray Sir, if your occasions call you not, do not go yet.

sp.speaker: Phill:
sp.p: Pollidor we know your civility is great, out discretion must not be the lesse, I see you are disturb'd, and know your pains are great upon you; make no reply, wee'l soon visit you againe; come Ordella, let us leave Selindra to her charge; good rest unto my friend, all joyes unto my Mistriss.

sp.speaker: Poll:
sp.p: Beshrew your kindnesse at this time, —how like Tantalus was I?

sp.speaker: Selin:
sp.p: What mean you by this passion brother? shall I call the Surgeons?

sp.speaker: Poll:
sp.p: No Selindra, they have no skill in my disease.

sp.speaker: Selin:
sp.p: You speak, and look, as if you wanted sleep, pray retire to rest.

sp.speaker: Poll:
sp.p: Rest Selindra! where can I find rest? Phillocles has taken all rest from me! did you not observe how the Princess came to me? and how she threw her favours on me! when in the height of all my joy, your approach destroyed me.

sp.speaker: Selin:
sp.p: If this be all! I must smile, to hear you sigh brother.

sp.speaker: Poll:
sp.p: All Selindra! doest thou mock me? are thy own flames so weak? thou smilest at mine!

sp.speaker: Selind:
sp.p: I cannot chuse but smile, when I rejoyce to see my wishes fall so fast upon me: you love the Princess, and she will love you, she must, she shall, nay, I doubt she does already! and have some fear, the work will be too easie, if I undertake it.

sp.speaker: Poll:
sp.p: Now thou mockest me more, then thou didst before! prithee Selindra be serious, and do not play with what torments me.

sp.speaker: Selin:
sp.p: What can be more serious? then to make a marriage between so great a Princess, and the King of Hungary? pray where can she make a better choice? or who can better plead your suit then I? Look to your wounds brother, leave this affair to me. Exit:

sp.speaker: Poll:
sp.p: My best wishes do attend thee, she has rais'd in me such doubtfull hopes, that they begin to vanish with her, and such fears to lose what I never had, do throng so fast upon me, that on the sudden I am orewhelm'd,—

lg.l: —With doubts, with joyes, with fears, so strangely mixt!
My heart is Hell, untill my hopes be fixt.

div.head: THE FIFTH ACT.

sp.speaker: Cecro:
sp.p: GOod day unto the bright Selindra?

sp.speaker: Selin:
sp.p: May your Lordship find many such.

sp.speaker: Cecro:
sp.p: Why do you sly me, Madam? I come in dilligence to make known to you, what concerns you more, then any other businesse can, towards which you make such haste from me.

sp.speaker: Selin:
sp.p: I fled not from your Lordship, nor did I perceive, that you had ought to say to me; what is your pleasure now?

sp.speaker: Cecro:
sp.p: My businesse is, to preserve you from a certain ruine, and to set you above the reach of mischiefe, as high in honour, as you are in beauty, and in vertue.

sp.speaker: Selind:
sp.p: I were much unworthy such a favour, and not Mistress of any virtue, if I should not return a befitting gratitude.

sp.speaker: Cecro:
sp.p: Know then Selindra, you are design'd unto your grave; your wedding robe, will prove your winding sheet, if I prevent it not; the Emperor puts on this shew of kindnesse, onely to destroy you with lesse noise; he does consent that Phillocles by a present marriage, should satisfie his appetite; after which you shall be poysoned, that the Prince may have no object between him and Astella: This by all our Grecian Gods is true, and this I have consented to.

sp.speaker: Selin:
sp.p: Can there be such a wickedness 'mongst men!

sp.speaker: Cecro:
sp.p: Can you doubt it, that have seen so much? or can you think Lascares will consider such a life as yours, when it does interpose between the Crown of Hungary and him?

sp.speaker: Selin:
sp.p: If this be so, how can I avoid it? shall I think you will betray the Emperors trust, to oblige me!

sp.speaker: Cecro:
sp.p: Madam, if you would please to look on your faithfull servant with equal Eyes, and on your dangers with judicious thoughts, you'l see that Phillocles his love brings death; —and Pollidor methinks, should not have gain'd an interest where Phillocles pretends.

sp.speaker: Selin:
sp.p: My Lord, I must confesse what you have said, is worthy my most serious thoughts, —but my Lord, 'tis not fit that I treat farther in this affaire, until my Father doth return; if you please to move him in it, my obedience shall follow his will.

sp.speaker: Cecro:
sp.p: Of his consent I make no doubt, my best Mistriss; joyes, and greatnesse do attend Selindra when she smiles on me!

div.stage: [She suffers him to kisse her Hand.]

sp.speaker: Selind:
sp.p: But how can you secure your self, and me from Phillocles? will not his rage, raise a revenge as ruinous, as this you would have me fly from?

sp.speaker: Cecro:
sp.p: Good Madam, let not so mean a thought remain with you; I have Lascares Scepter in my hand, and all the Frontier Towns in my Command; the Souldiers too, since Phillocles forsook them, are become mine; if my fair Mistress would by one kind look confirme my joyes, it would encourage me to let her see, at what a rate I value her.

sp.speaker: Selin:
sp.p: I blush to think that I have smil'd so much, upon so short acquaintance, Pray Heaven you have not a design, to destroy me this way!

sp.speaker: Cecro:
sp.p: Can you think I will destroy my souls onely joy? to remove all such fears, I will now put my life into your hands.

sp.speaker: Selin:
sp.p: How my Lord! your life?

sp.speaker: Cecro:
sp.p: You have heard, Madam, how the Hungarian Army marches towards Grecce, it does so: drawn in by me, to my aid they come, to assist me to get Selindra, and to set Lascares Crown upon her head! if she will deserve it? —we are interrupted now, —think on me, and thou shalt wear this Imperial Crown, Selindra, within few howers.

sp.speaker: Phil:
sp.p: What has caus'd thy clouded brow Selindra? has that viper vext thee?

sp.speaker: Selin:
sp.p: He has frighted me, and will anger us all, if he be not prevented; such horrid mischiefes he has in love to me reveal'd, as I shake to think on.

sp.speaker: Ordella.
sp.p: To what tune runne they?

sp.speaker: Selin.
sp.p:
To several tunes, some to Love, some to private blood-shed, others to publick Warre, and in summe to ruine all that's good; —The
Emperor will permit our marriage Sir, and after poyson me, that you may have leisure to gaine Astella; but above all, Cecropius treachery must be lookt to; He has call'd in the Hungarian Army, to make me his by force: he talked of a Crown too, that I should weare, if I would comply with him, and at that word you interrupted us: good Sir, make it a little more your businesse to prevent these Devils, and their designes.

sp.speaker: Phill:
sp.p: There is danger in this, worthy our best care, Selindra, I see our stay here, will still occasion new designs on us.

sp.speaker: Ordel:
sp.p: And you too late, I fear, will find my counsel good, why may not I have credit to protect Pollidor in your absence?

sp.speaker: Phill:
sp.p: I think you may, but yet 'tis not fit to hazzard such a friend, to the fury of that Monster Cecropius; besides, Selindra is now engaged in honour, to stay for him.

Truly Sir, I think I am in honour bound, not rashly to throw away a man, that has preserv'd us both; but Sir, when you shall consider that his wounds do now permit him to walk abroad, a few dayes more, will get him strength to ride with us: during which time, I can secure all by dissembling a little kindnesse to Cecropius, by which, I shall also discover his treaty with the Hungarians.

sp.speaker: Ordel:
sp.p: Pollidor is much oblig'd to you Selindra, I like well this noble humour in you.

sp.speaker: Phill:
sp.p:
It does become her, my dear Sister, it shall be my care to look after Cecropius now, and if necessity require, I will remove him speedily; I must leave you for some houres Ordella, to attend my Father; Farewel, my bright Mistriss; pray let your care continue unto Pollidor, and let not fall your kindnesse to Cecropius, he may confesse to you, what no tortures can draw from him.
Exit Phillocles.

sp.speaker: Selind:
sp.p: It does concern me Sir.

sp.speaker: Ord:
sp.p: It does indeed, Selindra, thy gratitude to Pollidor, looks hansomely; methinks as he recovers health, he growes comely, he seems to me, as if he were above the ordinary rank of men, I dare say he has a Noble Soule.

sp.speaker: Selin:
sp.p: Madam, you judge right, did you converse as I do daily with him, you should wonder at such worth; methinks I see greatness in his looks, and do observe that he holds in that lustre, with more advantage, then others shew it forth:

sp.speaker: Ord:
sp.p: He is sure some great Prince disguis'd, Selindra! and a happy man he is, that has found one that can discover his conceal'd perfections to the life!

sp.speaker: Tened:
sp.p:
Madam, my Master is now awake, and begs the favour of a visit.
Exit Tenedor.

sp.speaker: Selin:
sp.p: I shall follow your Lordship, when I have brought the Princess to her Chamber.

sp.speaker: Ord:
sp.p: Is he a Lord too, Selindra?
Did I call him Lord, Madam?

sp.speaker: Ord:
sp.p:
Ask when you see him next, go Selindra; this Ceremony to
me is needlesse, I shall find the way alone; 'tis fitter that you attend your charge, Pollidors wounds will not heal out of thy fight, Selindra: —I cannot chuse but wonder what kind of entertainment you can find, for so many houres, with so great a stranger, as Pollidor!

sp.speaker: Selin:
sp.p: Sure she is jealous, and I have been too free in praising him; —Pollidor and I, do spend more houres discoursing of Ordella's beauties, then of all other matters; he admires your perfections, Madam; his other wounds are slight, compar'd with those, he received from your eyes: for—

sp.speaker: Ordel:
sp.p: Hold, Selindra, I delight not in such saucy thoughts from Pollidor, nor does it become you to heare, much less to relate them unto me: I do feare Selindra, you hope by this invention, to dazle my Eyes, that I may not discover your own affection to this Pollidor; take heed you fall not from that vertue you are valued for, if you do deceive my trust, or Phillocles his love! you will be neither worthy his anger, nor my pitty.

sp.speaker: Selin:
sp.p: Let me fall under the weight of both your angers, when I deserve ill from either of you, your jealousie afflicts me Madam.

sp.speaker: Ordell:
sp.p: I hear my Brother coming, retire, that he may not see thy tears, and meet me in the Garden after supper, then I will hear more of this, and till then, suspend my Jndgment of thee.

sp.speaker: Phil:
sp.p: Why went Selindra weeping out? and what troubles you my Dear Sister?

sp.speaker: Ordel.
sp.p: I am not troubl • d now Sir: pray how did you find my Father? in what temper is he?

sp.speaker: Phill:
sp.p: Well Ordella, all is safe yet; but I cannot be satisfied untill you tell me why Selindra weeps; — your silence will beget doubts more troublesome, then the knowledge can be.

sp.speaker: Ordel:
sp.p: 'Twas nothing but an Argument that fell between us.

sp.speaker: Phil:
sp.p: That Argument Ordella, if thou lov'st my peace, that Argument!

sp.speaker: Ordel:
sp.p: I may wrong Selindra by it, and trouble you without a cause, when I am certainly informed, you shall be so, till then, pray do not urge me farther.

sp.speaker: Phil:
sp.p: I am so weak a man in thy esteem, thou darest not trust me with my self; Ordella, thy discourse will disturb me much, unless thou lettest me know the whole matter.

sp.speaker: Ordel:
sp.p: My unwillingnesse to tell you, is now become the onely cause I feare to do it, for I was questioning Selindra onely, about her frequent visits to Pollidor, which it seems I put into such Language, as made her weep; this on my credit is the truth, are you now satisfied?

sp.speaker: Phil:
sp.p: I am satisfied that we have the same thoughts, your judgement on this matter, confirms my Observations, which till now, took no hold on me; —If she prove false, thus I can blow her off; —But Pollidor, shall pay deare for his Treachery.

div.stage: Enter to them Pollidor, very weak in Rich Cloaths; a staff in his hand.

sp.speaker: Polli.
sp.p: Madam, 'tis fit that I visit you before the Temple, and pay my first vowes at your shrine, offering up a Life devoted to your Service.

sp.speaker: Ordel:
sp.p: You owe your health Sir, next to the Gods, unto Selindra's care, such a gratitude I have not seen before, nor such a zeale as hers, to serve you.

sp.speaker: Polli:
sp.p: My obligations to Selindra, I must rank after the Honours I have received from you Madam: —Pray Sir, how does the Emperor, [He turns to Phillocles.] and Cecropius, take this fained love between Selindra and me? how does it work with them?

sp.speaker: Phill:
sp.p: Since Selindra dwelt with you, the whole Court believes it is a mutuall Love; onely my Sister and my self, have other thoughts.

sp.speaker: Polli:
sp.p: (Those last words came coldly out, I must remove this jealousie;) I am glad Sir that you are secur'd by it, and I am joy'd to have a hand in any thing, that shall conduce to serve you, I do professe my Medicines have not so much wrought my cure, as the joy I have to see such unparalleld Virtues, and Affections meet, as is yours, and the good Selindra's; day day she tires her tongue in praising Phillocles, and stiil growes fresh, by talking of you Sir; I cannot wish you greater happinesse on Earth, then you will have with her, may it last while you last, and may Eternall Curses light on those that wish it less.

sp.speaker: Phil:
sp.p: I thank you Sir, and will hope to prosper, as you pray for me, and next to Selindra, and my Sister, place you by my heart.

sp.speaker: Polli:
sp.p:
You Honour me too much, and will make me proud, I must take my leave Sir, my strength is not yet enough confirm'd, to stay long abroad.
Exit Pollidor.

sp.speaker: Phil:
sp.p: The Gods go with thee, thou Man of Honour.

sp.speaker: Ordel:
sp.p: What think you Brother of this Complement?

sp.speaker: Phil:
sp.p: I think him really, what he seems.

sp.speaker: Ordel:
sp.p: I wish I could do so too, but when I call to mind that Selindra unto me, did talk just thus of Pollidor, as he now discours'd to you of her, methinks it looks like a designe.

sp.speaker: Phil:
sp.p: Does Pollidor presume to pretend to you?

sp.speaker: Ordel:
sp.p: So Selindra would have me think, which indeed was the main cause of my anger, and her Tears.

sp.speaker: Phill:
sp.p: I am not willing to be jealous, nor yet so fond, as not to be sensible, when there is just cause; Ordella let us smooth our browes, and observe them farther, such a guilt cannot be long hid, and untill we be confirm'd by some better proof, 'tis unworthy in us to suspect them, on our surmises only, since what they do, is by our direction.

sp.speaker: Ordel:
sp.p: 'Tis not my nature to judg ill of any, and I hope Selindra will deserve better; I am converted, and now we are thus secure, why may not you go to the Army, and leave Selindra with me; Pollidor in your absence, may Court her in publick, which will confirm my Father in his mistake, when he sees me dislike it.

sp.speaker: Phill:
sp.p: I like it well Ordella: what will you do this Evening?

sp.speaker: Ordel:
sp.p: I have some businesse for a while; Selindra after supper, will meet me in the Garden, pray come to us there.

sp.speaker: Phil:
sp.p: Bid your Boy attend us with his Lute then, it may so happen that I must take leave this night, for I hear that the Hungarian Army comes on apace.

sp.speaker: Ante:
sp.p: The Emperor sends you word Sir, that Cecropius has deliver'd all the Frontier Towns to the Hungarians, and himself advances in the head of that Army towards us.

sp.speaker: Phil:
sp.p: Dispatch a Post unto Antillacus, bid him advance towards the Traytor, I will this night set forth, and by day break shall reach him.

sp.speaker: Ante:
sp.p: Sir, Antillacus retreats before the Enemy, his men fewer in Number, are so disheartned by Cecropius's revolt, they dare not look on the Hungarians.

sp.speaker: Phil:
sp.p: Let the Page call Pollidor, to my Sisters Chamber presently, we will take leave there, and depart immediatly; Come Ordella, this is somewhat quicker work then I expected; bid my servants make what hast they can, to meet me here at my return.

div.stage: [Enter Periander with a Lady, as in Ordella's Chamber.]

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: My Lord, since you went hence, the Court has been in daily Tumults about Phillocles his Love unto your Daughter.

sp.speaker: Perian:
sp.p: Is Selindra so much in favour with the Gods, as to be look'd on by Prince Phillocles?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: The Prince seeks no other Heaven but her, and as the World thinks she neglects him, and Loves one Pollidor.

sp.speaker: Perian:
sp.p: Madam, I cannot raise my Faith to what you say, nor can I joy in such a blessing, untill I know the Emperor does approve it; pray Madam, where may I find Selindra?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: She is now with the Princess in the Garden, I shall let her know your Lordship is return'd.

sp.speaker: Perian:
sp.p: You obliege me Madam; —though I have been long absent, I have not been Idle, nor could I well have made more haste hither, cousidering how many great Affairs I have dispatch'd, since I went hence.

sp.speaker: Selin:
sp.p: Oh Sir! you are welcome, I have with some trouble, and some fear expected your Returne.

sp.speaker: Peri:
sp.p: Madam, I stay'd the longer, by reason of those Tumults I found at Belgrade, a false Astella was set up by Euticus, and his faction, but so soon as I made known, that you liv'd, both sides laid down their Arguments, though not their Armes, which I advis'd as the best means to bring you home in safety.

sp.speaker: Selin:
sp.p: But why does our Army enter Greece.

sp.speaker: Perian:
sp.p: That's the riddle Madam, the old Fox Cecropius gave notice to the Hungarians, that the Emperor purpos'd in his own person to invade them, since Phillocles had refus'd it, and would by a conquest joyn that Crown to his Empire; he insinuates also, that if the Hungarians would assist him in his design, he would make the Emperor unable to harme them, by delivering up all the Frontier Towns into their hands.

sp.speaker: Selin:
sp.p: And what is his design?

sp.speaker: Perian:
sp.p: Onely by their power, to force the Emperor to deliver you, and one Pollidor up to him: This I perswaded Orsanes, and the rest to hearken too, and my long stay was to see the Towns deliver'd to Orsanes, which is done, and Cecropius fooll'd by his vaine hopes, Marches in the head of your Army, which comes on apace, only to receive your Commands Madam.

sp.speaker: Selin:
sp.p: The Gods reward you, for I never can; —but here is Newes Periander, beyond what you tell; Pollinesso Lives, lives here under the name of Pollidor; and see where he comes; —Oh! my Brother we [Enter Pollidor.] are happy above our wish; this is Periander, who has so much obliged me.

sp.speaker: Polli:
sp.p: I hope I shall live to thank you Sir.

sp.speaker: Peri:
sp.p: Sir, I am rewarded in the good I have done, if my services do prove such in your esteem.

sp.speaker: Selin:
sp.p: My Brother, you must dispatch Periander back unto the Army, to give Orsanes and the rest, notice that you live; —Cecropius has rendred all the Towns, and comes on demanding to have me deliver'd to his lust.

sp.speaker: Poll:
sp.p: Wee shall order him at leisure, our care to informe Orsanes, must indeed be speedy; —Periander, though I cannot command, I may intreat you that know our Affaires, to return unto Orsanes, and give him notice, that I intend this night, to set forth with Phillocles, and will come over to him, with my first opportunity; bid him march fairly through the Country, and take heed that Antillacus ingage him not to fight, till I Arrive; if you ride hard; you may be back with us, before we part from hence, for I hear Cecropius is not far off.

sp.speaker: Peri:
sp.p: By my speed Sir, judge my Zeal to serve you.

sp.speaker: Poll:
sp.p: As you passe by my Lodgings, pray send all my servants to attend me in the next Room, from hence we shall take Horse this Evening; —Now Astella, methinks the Gods do smile on Hungary, and [Exit Periander.] on us; if Ordella would be gracious! Pollinesso were most happy; How does my Love prosper, Astella?

sp.speaker: Selin:
sp.p: I can make no certain Judgment on it yet.

sp.speaker: Poll:
sp.p: Canst thou not procure me one smile before we part?

sp.speaker: Selin:
sp.p: 'Twill not be possible, if you depart this night; I could wish we had more time, because I now propose some pleasure in my woeing for you; methinks the storms that I have rais'd, look merrily, now the calm is certain, and so nigh, I have so light a heart, that I could play with dangers, if any were within my reach. [They sit.]

div.stage: To them Enter Phillocles, and Ordella, who stand unseen behind them, sitting on the Couch.

sp.speaker: Poll:
sp.p: Let me Embrace and Kisse thee, my Dear, Dear Selindra; thou art so great a Joy unto my Soul, that I lament to part one minute from thee; when we meet next, we shall Embrace more freely. Embraces.

sp.speaker: Selin:
sp.p: That you must go from me, grieves me; must you needs go with Phillocles? may you not stay one day longer with me?

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: I dare not, do not weep thus, thy Tears will prove ill Omens, and I become a superstitious fool, to fear I know not why!

sp.speaker: Selin:
sp.p: How can I chuse but lament to part with, what is dearer to me then my life; pray do not go this night, bestow this night on me.

sp.speaker: Polli:
sp.p: I swear thou makest me sad, prethee speak more chearfully, and dry thy Eyes, least Phillocles perceive thy Tears, and Ordella do discover us, and so unmask us both, before we be prepar'd.

sp.speaker: Selin:
sp.p: No matter for their jealousie, are not we above the reach of malice now?

div.stage: Phillocles drawes, and offering to strike, is held by Ordella.

sp.speaker: Polli:
sp.p: Not yet Selindra, we may be ere-long, till then, 'tis not good to provoke any, it is by your advice to, that we should be still disguis'd.

sp.speaker: Selin:
sp.p: Yes, and 'tis my opinion still; but when Phillocles is gone who can discover us?

sp.speaker: Phil:
sp.p: The Gods, who will not suffer such impiety to be longer hid, let me loose Ordella, and I will cut these twisted Monsters into Atomes that their united Souls, may so expire together.

sp.speaker: Polli:
sp.p: Why thus inraged Sir?

sp.speaker: Phil:
sp.p: Canst thou ask false man? we have heard and seen, all that has past between ye.

sp.speaker: Poll:
sp.p: It may be so, and yet be mistaken, in all you have heard, and seen too; —Sir, if you will have a little patience, you shall see your mistake, and be sorry for this injurious Language, when you know to whom you speak.

div.stage: Phillocles offers to runne at him, but is held by Ordella.

sp.speaker: Selin:
sp.p: Good Madam, perswade the Prince to hear us, and there will be no cause to fight.

sp.speaker: Ordel:
sp.p: Thou worst of Women, how dares thy lips move towards me?

sp.speaker: Selin:
sp.p: For Heavens sake Madam hear us, you will too late repent this rashnesse else; we are both as innocent, as you can wish.

sp.speaker: Ordel:
sp.p: Brother you may do well to hear them, and revenge at leasure; pray lay by this anger for a while, and take it up again, when you see cause; they are in your power to punish, as you please.

sp.speaker: Phill:
sp.p: I thank thee Ordella, they are so; —I am tame, and now you may say on.

sp.speaker: Poll:
sp.p: Sir, if you have heard; and seen what past between us, I do confess you have reason for your anger, and our fondnesse doth deserve blame, but not death; 'tis true, that we have negligently shew'd, what we might better have conceal'd; necessity therefore now compells us to discover what we yet meant not to do, that our Innocency may no longer suffer.

sp.speaker: Phil:
sp.p:
Your Innocence!
Exit Phillocles.

sp.speaker: Polli:
sp.p: Madam, the Prince his absence, gives me opportunity to begge your pardon for Selindra, and my self, who have too long hid our affections from you, and our selves also; for she is my Sister, and will ere long, appear worthy Phillocles his best thoughts, and I do hope my self, when I shall dare to be my self, may have leave to say, my life is vowed to serve you.

sp.speaker: Ordel:
sp.p: Sir, you are mistaken, I am not to be deceved by this slight trick; — you would gaine time to escape my brothers vengeance.

sp.speaker: Polli:
sp.p: No Madam, you will shortly see, I am above it; and if—

sp.speaker: Phillo:
sp.p: Seize on that Traytor.

div.stage: [Pollidor steps to the other Door, and calls alone.]

sp.speaker: Poll:
sp.p: Tenedor, Periander, Tecknor, Treason; —what means this madnesse [They enter, and both parties stand ranged on either side.] Phillocles? a reasonable man should hear another speak; if I do not satisfie all your doubts, you shall find that I dare meet your fury; and shall raise stormes as high, as you can wish to see.

sp.speaker: Phil:
sp.p: Pray unfold this mistery, I do attend you.

div.stage: Pollidor leads Selindra to Phillocles who steps back from her.—

sp.speaker: Polli:
sp.p: Let this pledge speak for us both, for I can have no other interest, then to give her up into your Armes Sir, send your Guards off, and this riddle shall be as easie, and as pleasant, as it now looks harsh, [Phillocles steps back.] —Phillocles will blush, when he shall know from whom he slyes, and by whose hand offer'd to him.

sp.speaker: Phil:
sp.p: I understand you not, nor do I care; —hark, what noyse is this?

div.stage: Enter the Emperor, with his Train, and his Guard, swords drawn, crying, Arme, Arme, as they enter.

sp.speaker: Emp:
sp.p: What's this? a Warre within his owne Walls; Phillocles is this a time for private brawls? when the Hungarians are at your Gates?

sp.speaker: Phill:
sp.p: I am ready to depart Sir; and shall send them back, much faster then they now come on; I beg your pardon Sir, for my neglect.

sp.speaker: Emp:
sp.p: What Newes brings Gillon?

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: Antillacus sends you word Sir, that you must prepare to receive him with the Army, under the Town Walls, his souldiers have so many pannick fears, he dares not lead them out, to face the Enemy, he also wishes that Prince Phillocles would draw out the Court Regiments, to hearten his dejected men.

sp.speaker: Emp:
sp.p: I think 'twere better to receive them within the Walls, untill their shame, do out-face their fears; Tell Antillacus, my old Armes are on, and that I will my self strike the Traytor in the face.

sp.speaker: Phil:
sp.p: Hast back good Gillon, and tell Antillacus; if he can defend his Camp till I Arrive, I wish him not to move this way; my looks will send those ungratefull people home, if not, I have a flame within me, will consume them all. —I beg your pardon Sir, for my neglect.

sp.speaker: Emp:
sp.p:
Repaire it by your speedy succour, I shall take present order for what the Town can afford us.
Exit the Emp:

sp.speaker: Phil:
sp.p: Ordella, I have a Warre within, that will consume me.

sp.speaker: Orde:
sp.p: I hope this great Affair will divert your thoughts, and remove your trouble.

sp.speaker: Phil:
sp.p: For some few dayes it may; —farewell my Dear Sister; —and when I return, you shall hear from me Sir.

sp.speaker: Polli:
sp.p: I shall not stay behind you Sir, my wounds is not so ill, are to keep me from waiting on you; when this hurry, and your anger is over, I hope you will be at leasure to hear me out, and be pleas'd rather to finde you can be mistaken, then me guilty.

sp.speaker: Phil:
sp.p: I will by no means suffer it, 'twill be no charity, to permit you to hazzard Selindra's interest, by new dangers.

sp.speaker: Polli:
sp.p: Sir, your scornes, shall have no more power to stay me, then your anger has, I will along.

sp.speaker: Phil:
sp.p: But you shall not; I do suspect you will betray me to your Country-men, and dare not trust you with me.

sp.speaker: Pol:
sp.p: All this will not do, I know you do not doubt me that way? and I do swear, unlesse you break the bonds of Hospitality, (and do imprison me) I will along.

sp.speaker: Phil:
sp.p: And I will rather do it, then have your company, if you desist not.

sp.speaker: Poll:
sp.p: Phillocles will not so much blemish his great Name! imprison me that sav'd your life; —me, that am vowed to stand, or fall with you; — Sir, I must chide you now, you do too long hold up a causelesse anger, you know not why; too long neglect the great Affair that calls you hence; — I will stay no longer for you, but go do the work, before you come.

sp.speaker: Phill:
sp.p: Stay Pollidor, thou hast confounded all my reason, such a mixture of Noblenesse, nee'r met with such a Treachery till now; though I do know thee false, and do resolve with my own hand to Kill thee; I will trust thee this way, and do now intreat thee to stay till to morrow, that my Father comes.

sp.speaker: Poll:
sp.p: I Obey.

sp.speaker: Phil:
sp.l: Oh! my dear Sister, once more farewell,
I am now fall'n from Paradice to Hell.

sp.speaker: Ordel:
sp.l: The Gods go with you, and your action bless,
While I retire, and pray for your successe.

sp.speaker: Poll:
sp.p: We will be gone Selindra, and face Phillocles, in the head of our own Army; —what newes Periander?

sp.speaker: Peri:
sp.p: Sir, I am come to fetch you to your Army, I can convey you thither, before you are mist here.

sp.speaker: Selin:
sp.p: We are ready now, how farre off is the Army?

sp.speaker: Peri:
sp.p: You may hear their Drums Madam, at the City Gates.

sp.speaker: Poll:
sp.l: Come, let us hasten to our Troops: —
When instruments of Warre, from Warre release,
'Tis a good Omen, to a happy peace. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter at one Doore the Emperor, Phillocles, Antillacus, Armanthus, Gillon, and the Grecian Army.
Enter at the other Door Cecropius, Orsanes, and other Lords with the Hungarian Army.

sp.speaker: Emp:
sp.p: Thou art a bold ill man Cecropius, thou art ungratefull to thy Country, and my trust.

sp.speaker: Cecro:
sp.p: Sir, I have but hid my gratitude under this old Armor, which is onely now put on, to obtain what my prayers could not, — I demand justice Sir, for Cleonels blood, which you have hitherto denied me, in favour to his Murtherers.

sp.speaker: Emp:
sp.p: This fained modesty, is more impudent, then thy Armes are, thou knowest I was more eager then thy self, to do justice on those that slew thy Son, and thou seest clearly, our Lawes cannot touch them for his fall.

sp.speaker: Cecro:
sp.p: Was not Cleonel slain by Pollidor? and was not Selindra accessary? and does not our Lawes condemn such Murtherers to Dye?

sp.speaker: Emp:
sp.p: No, thou knowest they do not, thou knowest thy Son was by a just hand punish'd, and that Pollidor deserves prayse and reward.

sp.speaker: Phil:
sp.p: Good Sir, spend no more breath on this vile man, the slave is not worthy your anger: — Foolish Hungarians, ingratefull perjur'd people: — Orsanes, I did not look for this from you; —but my sword shall speak my vengeance. [Offers to Charge.]

sp.speaker: Orsan:
sp.p: Prince Phillocles has not in Grcece a more faithful servant then Orsanes; Pray Sir lay by this passion but a few minutes, and you shall see that I have labour'd hard, to bring your own desires, to their wish'd ends: — and Cecropius the main Agent in it all!

sp.speaker: Phil:
sp.p: Why do your Actions, and your words so disagree? Orsanes knowes our Grecian hearts cannot be compell'd, when we have time to draw our Swords.

sp.speaker: Orsan:
sp.p: Great Sir, your actions, have enought declar'd your worth unto the World, and to our Nation most; which we shall ever own, though now by some necessity compell'd, we do appear as enemies, in the behalf of this good man, who has ingag'd us to deliver up a Lady call'd Selindra, and one Pollidor, to his hands, which he by strong arguments assur'd us, would be for your, and for our future happinesse: this done, we are all at Phillocles command.

sp.speaker: Phil:
sp.p: Those two you mention, are of late become unworthy of my thoughts; yet your engagement was barbarous, to undertake you know not what: sound the charge.

sp.speaker: Orsan:
sp.p: Hold Phillocles, I have entertain'd you with discourse thus long, only till I might hear that shout behind us: —hark, hark, Sir! Now the time is come, for us to keep our Oaths made to Cecropius, and to manifest our love to Phillocles, —make way there for the King.

div.stage: The Hungarian Army opens, and through them enter Pollinesso crown'd, leading in Astella; Orsanes delivers them both unto Cecropius.

sp.speaker: Phill:
sp.p: What Riddle's this? what wonders do I see?

sp.speaker: Cecro:
sp.p: Take away that shadow of a King, to present death Orsanes; and now Selindra you are once more at my dispose: and you Sir, that think you can command the World! shall find this weak old Arm, can justifie my title here.

sp.speaker: Orsan:
sp.p: Have I now perform'd my oath unto the great Cecropius?

sp.speaker: Cecro:
sp.p: You have.

sp.speaker: Orsan:
sp.p: I must then set this Lady free, from the danger of our Swords. — [A shout of joy.]

div.stage: [He delivers Astella to Pollinesso, and kneels.]

sp.speaker: Orsan:
sp.p: Long live the King of Hungary.

sp.speaker: Cecro:
sp.p: I am betrayed.

sp.speaker: Phill:
sp.p: Pollidor! and Selindra! why is he crown'd!

sp.speaker: Emp:
sp.p: They are confederates with Cecropius, on which design they have thus long liv'd amongst us.

sp.speaker: Poll:
sp.p: Orsanes, lay that Monster, at his Masters feet; there to receive a Doom worthy his treachery, and ingratitude.

sp.speaker: Phill:
sp.p: Pollidor, what mean these misteries?

sp.speaker: Poll:
sp.p: All respects to Phillocles.

sp.speaker: Phil:
sp.p: How comes Selindra then with thee? and that Crown upon thy head? I tell thee Pollidor, if Selindra can neglect me, I can contemn her; and not envy thee that mis-becoming Crown thou wearest, which I will tear from off thy swelling browes, and trample on it, when 'tis mine by a second conquest.

div.stage: [Pollidor leads Selindra to Phillocles, and he retires.]

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: —Will Phillocles forsake the List? fly from such a foe! send for the Princess Ordella then, that we may meet on equall termes.

sp.speaker: Phil:
sp.p: You are merry Sir, my gentle temper I see, begets contempt from your great courage.

sp.speaker: Poll:
sp.p: No Sir, you are mistaken still, I am your servant, and do value Phillocles, more then he can contemne me: —Orsanes, bring my Standard hither: —carry this, and my Crown, unto the Princess Ordella; lay [Gives him his Crown.] them at her feet, and if she dains to take them up, tell her your King, with his whole people, do wait on her Commands.

sp.speaker: Phil:
sp.p: I understand not what these Riddles mean!

sp.speaker: Poll:
sp.p: If Phillocles be yet at leasure to hear me speak, I shall soon remove this wonder?

sp.speaker: Phil:
sp.p: If Pollidor prove worthy, I shall not trust my Eyes nor Ears for ever.

sp.speaker: Poll:
sp.p: But when Prince Phillocles shall know that Pollinesso speaks, he will believe no hand has more right, to deliver up Astella into his Arms, then I: Do you not know me yet Sir?

div.stage: He pulls off his Perriwig and patch from his Eye.

sp.speaker: Phil:
sp.p: Nor yet know my self! — Antillacus, do I wake? or is this a Phantosm that I think I see? [Phillocles stands amaz'd.]

sp.speaker: Ant:
sp.p: 'Tis as strange to me, Sir!

sp.speaker: Emp:
sp.p: While my Sons wonder lasts, let me imbrace you Sir, and obtaine both yours, and Astellas pardon, and chide you both in the same breath; why did you suffer us to walk so long in this unhappy darknesse? and runne so many hazzards, which this light would have avoided.

sp.speaker: Poll:
sp.p: There was no other way to obtain this light, while Cecropius eclips'd your glory Sir.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Does Pollinesso live? can he forget my crimes? and forgive my blindnesse!

sp.speaker: Pol:
sp.p: Can Phillocles pardon my concealment? by which he was so blinded? [They embrace.]

sp.speaker: Phill:
sp.p: There is but one happinesse on earth beyond holding Pollinesso thus!

sp.speaker: Poll:
sp.p: To me too, there can be onely one above it! —and that is Ordellas leave to love her: —but Sir, have you no room for Selindra in your heart? [Points to Selindra.]

sp.speaker: Phil:
sp.p: I dare not look that way: I dare not have a hope so high, as pardon from her. —I am so full of guilt, that I dare not live longer to think of my unworthinesse. [Offers to draw.]

sp.speaker: Selind:
sp.p: What have I done Sir, that you should be thus cruel to me! will you not look on me?

sp.speaker: Phil:
sp.p: I shall blush to death, if you speak thus again!

sp.speaker: Ast:
sp.p: Will Phillocles turn from me ever?

sp.speaker: Phil:
sp.p: Yes Madam, as asham'd to look on you; I have a guilt within, that takes my manhood from me! —shall I dare to think you can forgive my unworthy jealousie?

sp.speaker: Ast:
sp.p: If you can forgive me that provok'd you to it? I can meet you thus.

sp.speaker: Phil:
sp.p: And I, fall as low as Earth will let me, to receive your pardon.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: I am so much amaz'd at what I see, that I know not which way to turne me!

sp.speaker: Emp:
sp.p: This way, Ordella, if you will by me, be guided to felicity? —this is Pollinesso's wish too, if I mistake not!

sp.speaker: Polli:
sp.p: 'Tis my ambition Sir, my highest hope on this side Heaven.

sp.speaker: Ord:
sp.p: And my honour, that Pollinesso has such thoughts for me; but Sir, 'twill ask some time for me to raise my wishes to such a value of your worth, that we may meet on equal termes.

sp.speaker: Phil:
sp.p: Pollinesso's merit, and his worth is such, that when he sayes he Loves; —'tis argument enough to gaine the greatest Queen: — Ordella, the Gods smile upon us now: —and you, Sir, I hope concurre with Heaven in our Felicities.

sp.speaker: Emp:
sp.p: My prayers and my blessings shall not be wanting: let Pollinesso give sentence on Cecropius, before we go unto the Temple.

sp.speaker: Poll:
sp.p: Let him live for ever banish'd from this happy Climate, which he has so long polluted with his venimous breath.

sp.speaker: Emp:
sp.p:
Antillacus see it done.
Exit with Cecropius.

sp.speaker: Ast:
sp.p: Madam, can you pardon my disguise?

sp.speaker: Ord:
sp.p: I cannot well tell what to answer! to find Selindra worthy, is a concerne greater then Astella can be to me; and that you now are Astella, does not more raise my wonder, then that you were Selindra, does confirme my love, and my respects to you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Ast:
sp.p: I have a heart too full of joy to keep this distance any longer?

sp.speaker: Phi:
sp.l: We now loose time, that might be better spent,
In sacrificing for this blest event!

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Lead on then to the Temple, and proclaime
A publick feast, in bright Astellas name;
While we do march in a triumphant state,
That all the City may participate
Our joyes, now Phillocles captivity
Is chang'd into a triple Victory.

div.p: Written by Sr WILLIAM KILLIGREW, Vice-Chamberlane to Her MAIESTY.
OXFORD, Printed by Hen: Hall Printer to the UNIVERSITY, for Ric: Davis, 1666.

list.item: Cleandra, Queen of Ci • her • a.
Ormasdes, Her General, a Prince of Greece.
Embassador, from Valeriana King of Treconia.

div.head: THE SCENE In the Island of Citherea.
THE FIRST ACT.
div.stage: [Enter Menetius, and Nearcus; A Messenger meets them.]

sp.speaker: Mess:
sp.l: MY Lords, the Queen sends me to let you know
That she is safe, and her whole Fleet secure.

sp.speaker: Mene:
sp.l: The Queens safety, is welcome Newes to all,
Though from the Castle top, we saw the fight;
None could so clearly the success discern;
As to rejoyce for her security,
Till you arriv'd.

sp.speaker: Near:
sp.l: 'Twas bold, and bravely done, with lesse numbers
To assault so great a Fleet, so near home!
I wonder how they got Intelligence?
So just, to know the Queens return from Greece.

sp.speaker: Mess:
sp.l: To Assault us, was farre from their design;
They fell by chance amongst our Ships ith' night,
As they were passing by; found us secure,
And unprepar'd for such an accident:
So we together Sail'd, 'till day appear'd;
Then our great Admirall, and his brave Son,
With their two Squadrons, did begin the Fight:
—The Queens Ship was attaqued on every side,
In which, Ormasdes by the Gods was plac'd,
That by his hand, Cleandra might be freed,
As by a Miracle! her dangers such!
And his Achievements so beyond them all!
That my Relation, 'would Romance appear,
To tell you, how he acted every where.

sp.speaker: Men:
sp.l: I hope this accident, will now perswade
The Queen, that she no more such journies make:
Great Princes to such visits are not bound,
Where Complements do so great danger bring.

sp.speaker: Near:
sp.l: Though Cleandra's visit, may not admit
Of a State Argument to justifie
A danger; —She had reason to return
Some high respect, unto the Grecian Court,
Where she so long, in so great splendor liv'd,
Before she had this Citherean Crown:
Nor was it now amiss to shew the Power,
And Glory, of so great a Fleet, as Greece
Nee'r saw before! by which, our renew'd League,
Will be more valu'd, and our Nation fear'd.

sp.speaker: Mene:
sp.l: I have no Argument for a dispute;
—This visit past, she needs no other make;
But Sir, how comes Ormasdes here again?
What great Affair, occasions his return?

sp.speaker: Near:
sp.l: How can the Grecian Empire so long spare,
So great a Captain? and so much belov'd.

sp.speaker: Messen:
sp.l: That happy Emperor; who has no Warre,
Did give Ormasdes liberty once more,
To grant Cleandra's sute, for his return,
That he may now confirm, what he has wonne,
Lest his late Trophies in the Zelnian Warre,
Be tumbled down! for we may doubt! those Kings
Who border Zelnia, will not long indure
Such losse; as will Cleandra's Crown secure.
Though her great Ancestor that Kingdome won,
And left it to his most unhappy Son;
Who all those Princes Tributaries made.
That in Affection call'd him to their Aide.

sp.speaker: Mene:
sp.l: Harke Nearcus, harke how the People shout!
As if the Queen were now, come near the shore;
Pray Sir, command the Guards advance with speed,
Unto the Port; Nearcus, I do fear,
The Queen may land, while we are tri • ling here. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Cleandra Queen of Citherea, Ormasdes a Prince of Greece. Her Generall with his Arme in a Scarfe, Old Titus Admiral, Young Titus, Lords, Ladies, and Traine.

sp.speaker: Admi:
sp.l: The Gods have given you a full Victory,
And all your Fleet will be in Port, by Noon.

sp.speaker: Queen:
sp.l: I have thank'd the Gods, Titus, and do see
Yours, and your Sons merits, in this great work:
But have not words that can expresse my thanks
To brave Ormasdes, for preserving me;
Had you seen my danger, when the bold Turks
With assured Victory, my Cabin forc't!
And how by his hand, from that Ruine freed!
You would with me admire, if not adore
The force which Rescued, with so great a Power!
My fear, my wonder, and my joy, so mixt,
I had no time for any thought betwixt
My danger, and my safe deliverance,
Which did the price of that great work inhance!
The bloody Trophies of Ormasdes Sword;
Surpas'd what Mars to Hector did afford.

div.stage: [Ormasdes faints, and leans on Young Titus.]

sp.speaker: Adm:
sp.l: He faints, this remove to Land, makes him weak;
— How do you Sir?

sp.speaker: Ormas:
sp.l: My soul, Titus, shrunk away, much asham'd,
To hear my service by Cleandra fam'd,
Too much for any modest man to own,
That my weak Arm, should rescue her alone!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: I am amaz'd, thus suddainly to find
The Gods so cruel, who have been so kind!
Thus to Eclips the joyes they freely gave,
Shews they repent the mercy, which did save;
Ormasdes death, will now so dismall be,
I cannot sacrifice for Victory.
Unlesse the Fates this mischief do divert!
It will our Triumphs, into Tears convert.

sp.speaker: Y. Tit:
sp.l: His wounds shew not the danger you conceive;
Madam, you Prophesie so great an ill,
The Fates themselves, will tremble to fulfill.

sp.speaker: Ormas:
sp.l: I am well Madam, only blush to hear,
That my slight wounds, should be so much your care;
If great Cleandra, do mean Acts admire,
Brave men, will not to high Attempts aspire.

div.stage: Enter to them, Nearcus, Cleobulus, and Cithareans, they Kiss Cleandras hand, a noyse of joy within from the People.

sp.speaker: Cleo:
sp.l: Madam, the publick joy for your return,
Does shew how much we did your absence mourn.

sp.speaker: Qu:
sp.l: My Peoples joy brings me great happinesse,
And your love, my Lords, my true value has:
But still I must your gratitudes direct
Unto Ormasdes, by whose powerfull hand,
Cleandra was preserv'd, and now restor'd.

sp.speaker: Ormas:
sp.l: Madam, you reward my small endeavors done,
With praise above, the merit of a man!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: I can afford Ormasdes as much Worth,
And Honour, as the Antient Heroes had,
So he will me such gratitude allow,
As sutes with my great benefits receiv'd; —
— What Fleet Nearcus, lies within our Port?

sp.speaker: Near:
sp.l: 'Tis from Treconia Madam, here's Arriv'd
A brave Embassador, from that great King,
Who here has long expected your return;
His Equipage is Rich, and with him shines,
A Lady he calls Sister; hither come,
To wonder at the Glories of your Court,
While we do all admire, their Princely Port!

sp.speaker: Qu:
sp.l: He shall have present Audience, to excuse
His long attendance; give him a respect:
Beyond the reach, or thought of a neglect;
—Do you Nearcus, bring him to us now; —
— Cleobulus, what newes from Zelnia?

sp.speaker: Cl:
sp.l: The frontiers have been frequently attaqu'd,
Since you went hence, but no great dammage done.

sp.speaker: Ormas:
sp.l: I beg the honour Madam to chastise
Those haughty Rebels, for their Insolence.

sp.speaker: Qu:
sp.l: The whole World knowes, Ormasdes can command
The fortune of a Warre; why then should you?
As if your Name were yet obscure! desire
New dangers? But you covet a Renown,
Beyond the value of the Zelnian Crown;
Else, you'd secure my People from their fear,
By your consent to be my Vice-Roy there.

sp.speaker: Or:
sp.l: Such proffer'd gifts from Princes, are not us'd
To be neglected, and much lesse refus'd!
But I must not your Majesty permit,
To load me with an honour so unfit!
As will Eclips the merit you allow,
When gifts shine brighter, then my Actions do.

sp.speaker: Qu:
sp.l: Is there no way Ormasdes to remove
These niceties? must I for ever own
Your benefits? and make you no return!
How little do I seem to your great Eye?
Who scorn I should your service gratifie.

sp.speaker: Ormas:
sp.l: I have in Greece, all my relations left,
To serve you Madam, and am hither come,
With a sixt zeal to wish, and to obey,
What ever you command! and only fear
My inclination may my tongue direct,
To beg what you'l deny: though I affect.

sp.speaker: Qu:
sp.l: Though I your sute dislike, I will consent,
And from your happinesse, raise my content.

sp.speaker: Or:
sp.l: With your permission Madam, I would beg
Leave to retire unto the little Lodge,
Within the Forrest, half a League from hence,
Where after all my Travels, I may find
Ease for my body, and refresh my mind,
With the soft solace of a private life,
Free from Affairs, and Courts Eternal strife.

sp.speaker: Qu:
sp.l: This is farre beyond my fears Ormasdes!
'Tis no wonder you my favours slight!
When you do our society dislike.
But I will not your purpose now oppose,
Though I your counsels, and your friendship lose;
Who in debates can speak, in fight command,
And order all, that in disorder stand, —
—Can nothing alter your desire from this?

sp.speaker: Ormas:
sp.l: Not, unlesse troubles be preferr'd to bliss.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Ormasdes, it shall be as you desire,
And freely, when you please, you may retire.

sp.speaker: Ormas:
sp.l: Though I a while absent my self from Court,
I shall be ready to lay by my Books,
When you do call me to put Armour on,
Stories tell, that great men the like have done.

sp.speaker: Queen▪
sp.l: Though I know no example, I believe
What e're Ormasdes shall make choice to do,
May be a president, that will ingage
Brave men to follow, in the future Age.

sp.speaker: Ormas:
sp.l: Your Majesty in this, has given me more content

Then all the favours proffer'd me before.
Exit Ormasdes.

sp.speaker: Y. Tit:
sp.l: Is this his humour? or some fancy grown
From passion for some Love, to us unknown;

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: No, Titus, he has ever been observ'd,
A great contemner of Amores, and does
True friendship more esteem, then idle love.

sp.speaker: Y. Tit:
sp.l: The more like now to be so much concern'd,
When touch'd; our mortal bodies are so frail,
That we may love, and know not what we aile!
VVhy, does your Majesty think friendship can
VVith as much force as love, transport a Man?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Not to such frensies, as wild brains Create,
VVhen fancy cannot change the course of Fate—
—VVhen love to Faces with the Face decay,
A virtuous Friendship will for ever sway. —
—I wish you, Titus, when he first retires,
To try how farre your Friendship can prevail,
To get the secret from Ormasdes soul;
'Tis for his good, that he his griefs impart▪
True friendship will allow a little Art,
VVhen the design does nothing more import,
But bringing of Ormasdes back to Court.

sp.speaker: Tit:
sp.l: I shall be joy'd, and happy if I can
Bring back to Court! so Excellent a Man.

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.l: The Embassador attends your Majesty.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Admit Him. [The Queen sits.]

sp.speaker: Embas:
sp.l: Madam, my Master, the Treconian King,
Salutes you in these Letters, and by me,
Congratulates your Zelnian Victorie;
But does lament, that he no share acquir'd,
In that great Conquest, he so much desir'd:
He was ambitious, Madam, to command
In that near Warre, and not as neuter stand.
When strangers merits do such Triumphs claime,
While he to you unknown, sat still with shame.
But since Ormasdes conduct, and his skill,
With such high Valour, has fulfill'd your will.
He envies not so great a Souldiers praise,
But would have shar'd in his Triumphant Bayes.

sp.speaker: Qu:
sp.l: If I had known Valeriana's mind,
He might my thanks have shar'd, and not repin'd.

sp.speaker: Emb.
sp.l: I have commission also, to propose
A League between your Kingdomes, and your selves,
Such, as new Conquer'd Zelnia will secure,
That Cithereas peace, may long endure.—
—Your Beauty Madam, more then Crowns invite,
Valerianus wishes to unite
Your hearts; and then, your Scepters may
Be double fixt, when both do love obey.
He begs, that he in person may appear,
To plead his love, and treat this great affair.

sp.speaker: Queen:
sp.l: Valerianus friendship I approve,
But never shall consent to treat of Love;
'Twould raise my dead Lords Ashes in his Urn,
If I should to a second Lover turn?
Your great Kings proffer'd League, I do imbrace,
With fit Affection, and a chearfull face: —
Declaring to the World, how I respect,
His person, though I must his sute reject.

sp.speaker: Emb:
sp.l: I shall acquaint my Master, — and beg leave
I may your Majesties commands receive,
Without the Ceremonies that belong,
To a State audience, in a formal throng.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: You shall have free accesse, as you desire,
And now my Lord, I must a Sutor be,
That your faire Sister will in Court appear!
Who, I am told, is come to visit me.

sp.speaker: Emb:
sp.l: That, Madam, should have been my next request,
That you, my dearest Sister, would permit,
To kiss your hand, who does attend without.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Will you, Ormasdes, please to bring her in?
And make my excuse, who did not know

She was so neer.
Exit Ormas:
If you had brought her to the Audience!
She should have been as welcome as you wish.

sp.speaker: Emb:
sp.l: Though all the World adore Cleandras Name!
On the faint notions of a Common Fame:
I now can testify! and will declare,
Your virtues, to your beauties equall are.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Your compliments require not a reply,
You over-valew my civilitie.

sp.speaker: Qu:
sp.l: You do me, and my Country, honour more,
Then any Lady ever did before.

sp.speaker: Mar:
sp.l: I have done my self a favour Madam,
And 'tis your Majesty that honours me;
The fame of Citherea I confesse,
May Princes hither bring, but my address,
Is to Cleandras self, that I might see,
The virtue fam'd for such Divinitie.

sp.speaker: Qu:
sp.l: Madam, if you such flatteries throw out,
You will your welcome spoil, and make me doubt
You rather come to mock, then to admire!
On such another word? I shall retire.

sp.speaker: Mari:
sp.l: I can be silent Madam, while I live,
But must speak truth, when you this freedome give.

sp.speaker: Qu:
sp.l: We then will change our argument, and place,
Lest I do chide, whom I intend to grace.

div.stage: Exeunt all but Nearcus and Cleobulus.

sp.speaker: Cleob:
sp.l: Did you observe, with what forc'd modesty
The Embassador supprest his anger?
When his Masters sute, so briskly was denied.

sp.speaker: Near:
sp.l: Yes, and how suddain his sad looks changed,
When bright Cleandra did so soon admit
His private visits; as if himself were struck!
And did no further presse his Masters sute.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: I have other thoughts, that made me believe,
The Lady he calls Sister, is his Love.

sp.speaker: Near:
sp.l: Such things have been, and Mariana may
His Mistris be; whose beauty in my Eye,
Does farre surpasse Cleandras Majesty.
And now you put these thoughts into my head,
I did observe Marianus Eyes and his,
Did a long practiz'd silent language shew,
While they by turns did entertain the Queen.

sp.speaker: Cleob:
sp.l: But I had second thoughts, led me to think,
I did sometimes perceive Marianas Eyes,
On brave Ormasd • s fixt; and seem'd to take
Such a survey, as Purchasers do make.

sp.speaker: Near:
sp.l: I doubt Mariana has not an estate,
To purchase him, at great Cleandras rate.

sp.speaker: Cleo:
sp.l: Let us observe them better next, and see
If it be Art; or their simplicitie. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Emb:
sp.l: I have undone my self, Mariana!
For now beyond resistance I do love;
And find Cleandr will by her neglects,
Dash all my hopes, and turn from my respects.

sp.speaker: Mari:
sp.l: There does not a just cause to me appear,
For such a doubt; much lesse to raise dispair:
Because Cleandr runs not at first sight,
Into the Arms, of such a wandring Knight.
Though your State Arguments, cannot procure
To Treat; she may but a short Siege indure,
When as your self, a King you do appear!
The Castle may be won, by love, or fear.

sp.speaker: Emb:
sp.l: No Mariana, I have heard, and seen
Too much, the brave Ormasdes stands between
Me, and my happiness, his retirement
Is to cloke their close Love, and to prevent
Pretenders; or such scandal, as would rise,
If openly in Court, without disguise!
Such unproportion'd love should ere be known,
Which shewes they dare not their affections own.

sp.speaker: Mar:
sp.l: What need such dissembling? to hide that love,
Which all the Cithereans do approve;
And publickly do pray, his great Renown,
Might be rewarded with Cleandra's Crown.
To publick fame, I therefore credit give,
They not in love, but in true friendship live.

sp.speaker: Emb:
sp.l: Such friendship between man, and woman, may
'Mongst silly people make a holy-day.
No Callenders of mine, shall ere admit
Of a Red Letter, for a counterfet.

sp.speaker: Mar:
sp.l: The Gods defend, Brother.

sp.speaker: Emb:
sp.l: Why, Mariana? what is your concern?
To blush, because we do their crimes discern!
Can you believe, that a Platonick flame,
Has power to Canonize Cleandras Name?

sp.speaker: Mar:
sp.l: I blush for you, who now so boldly dare,
Against the person that you love! declare.

sp.speaker: Emb:
sp.l: Your words, and looks, do not at all agree,
But shame for your Ormasdes infamie.
He is the man in Marianas Eye,
Whose blushes would his vices justifie.

sp.speaker: Mari:
sp.l: Though I his virtues honour, and admire
The glorious Actions of his life, my heart
Is not in any danger to be lost.

sp.speaker: Emb:
sp.l: When a heart is so well lost, Mariana!
'Twill soon be found, I did believe my own,
As fast fixt as yours, yet at first sight
Of the fair Queen, 'twas from its center forc'd.

sp.speaker: Mari:
sp.l: I, Brother, your businesse was to lose it.

sp.speaker: Emb:
sp.l: But the blind Deity considers not
Our purposes, he wounds at randome still; —
—I wish thou wouldst ingeniously confesse,
If in thy thoughts Ormasdes be not grown
The handsomest, and gallantest of men;
Whose famous actions, in our western World,
May well excuse thy wonder, and thy Love;
— I wish thy beauties could his heart ingage,
That I might have no Rival for the Queen.

sp.speaker: Mari:
sp.l: To oblige my dear brother, I will try,
What may be done, for your security.

sp.speaker: Emb:
sp.l: Thy whole life, never can oblige me more▪
—Ormasdes is a great Prince in Greece,
And I for thee, will make him greater yet,
By my additions in Treconia;
If you can think him worthy of your Love?
—Our forces joyn'd, may double conquest gain;
When sever'd, both indeavours may prove vain.

sp.speaker: Mar:
sp.l: While you talk thus, I had as good confesse:
What you so much believe, and do allow,
I gladly would obtain, if I knew how.

sp.speaker: Emb:
sp.l: That was well said, let us to Councel then —
Suppose • Court the Queen in my own shape▪

sp.speaker: Mar:
sp.l: I think 'tis best that you do first inquire,
